Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2011 08:10AM susan_02143 wrote: Thank you for all your well wishes. What I know is that I didn't do anything in particular to get NED into my life. I mean, I took the pills everyday, and presented my butt monthly for a shot, but nothing more than anyone else here. I just got a lucky draw, for now. Lena, to answer your question, for the most part I don't have the ugly SE's. I have some bone pain, I have lost a few IQ points [which I really really miss] and some fatigue. Well within the acceptable bounderies however. This winter I had three months of no SE's, and boy was that nice. 3rings, yes. It is probably good that people in this waiting room have gotten older. I do miss seeing my familiar faces just a bit though. So a little story, I was in this waiting room, which was quite full, sitting next to a man that was probably old enough to be my Dad. One of the very well-meaning volunteers approached and asked this gentleman if he wanted a drink. Never offered me anything though. Then another volunteer approached, again to talk with this man, and in one of those almost baby voices said "And who are we here to see today? What time is your appointment?" and then looked at me! "We are not together. I am actually a patient" This man burst out into laughter. He wondered why "we" were waiting for anything. I did offer to let him adopt me if he owned an Island in Greece. Sadly, he didn't need anymore children, and did not own any islands.  Can I actually dance as a Stage IV patient? No. Could I dance before BC? No. However, I did do a small jig, or what I called a jig, after getting the scan results. I suspect it was not a pretty sight. Loved hearing that so many others have gotten good news recently. Been a hard two weeks here on BCO. *susan*

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2011 08:13PM susan_02143 wrote: Oh my Joanne, Our comments must have seemed harsh, and I can assure you that they are not intended that way. As a patient with mets, you can expect to be on some kind of treatment without too many breaks. That doesn't always means chemo however. Given that you are HER2+, you will probably be on a weekly herceptin. And the ER+ attributes mean that you could take one of the AI's, Tamoxifen and/or Faslodex [a monthly injection.] It is up to you to decide how much information you want from your oncologist. There is no right way to do this. Big hugs.... *susan*

Posts.Content: susan_02143 wrote: Today was the day.... to meet my new oncologist and to get my PET scan results. With a new oncologist comes a new waiting room, and new desk staff, and new volunteers. And they are all so much older! I must have been the youngest person in the waiting room by at least 20 yrs [and I am not a spring chicken!] After an endless wait [about 15 min] Nurse Lauren took me back to the room and dove right in. With a huge smile she said, "your scans look good." Of course I wanted to know how we were defining "good" and so she opened up the report. Nothing! There are many words in the report, two pages of words, but the bottom line, I am dancing with my boy NED!!!!!!!!! All three spots are gone! New oncologist will be okay. Still holding out judgement to be honest. She wants to bring me into line with a double dose of Faslodex instead of the single dose. She isn't as interested in the rest of my body as Dr. Roger, but for now I am not going to fire her. NED! Can you believe it? I am just beside myself.  anotherplan.blogspot.com... and its back. May 3, 2010 mets found. Five years NED on Faslodex * 4/2015 progression to bone * 6/11/2015 Femara/Ibrance * 12/27/2015 Xeloda * 2/24/2016 Xgeva * another progression, another drug Taxol 2/14/2017 Dx 6/8/2005, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIB, Grade 1, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 24, 2010 08:13PM susan_02143 wrote: This whole idea of a council seems so very male. What struck me the most, listening to this guy talk, was how against the idea his wife was. She negotiated hotly to limit the number of men that became part of this posse, hence why they ended up with 'specialists.' But we all want to feel like we have some modicum of control over the future. We know that we can't control our cancer [completely] so maybe we can control who raises our children, who marries our spouses and how our assets are distributed. This guy just took it to another level. If I think of it as the kids have 6 godfathers it doesn't strike me as odd, but if I think of it as five or six guys who will be the children's fathers, it moves into a realm that seems overly intrusive to the Mother he might leave behind. Can you tell I am torn by this idea? *susan*

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2012 01:50PM susan_02143 wrote: Susan, Welcome. There is no concensus about tumor markers. Some doctors use them; some don't. And some doctors use them long enough to determine whether or not they are indicative for a particular patient, and then only run them for those specific patients. I am one of the lucky ones that gets a very good view of what is happening inside with my tumor markers. Other people progress while their markers are going down or are stable. Overall, it sounds as though you need to ask your doctor to talk with you. *susan*

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2011 04:57PM susan_02143 wrote: Heather, I am going to start with your terror. Who told you that this is a sign of final stages? Do they have an MD at the end of their name? Ignore this comment unless it was from a medical professional. I, for one, have never heard this, but then again, I don't have an MD after my name either!  :-) Swelling in the hands and feet can indicate that you are retaining water or that you are not processing your waste well. Neither thing is great, but require different approaches. Since I have not had most of these drugs listed, I don't know if this is one of the side effects or not. I would put in another call the the oncologist on call to determine if this is life-threatening. While waiting for the callback, raise your feet on an ottoman or coffee table to encourage flow. Questions they might ask could be, how much have you been peeing in the past 24 hrs, over what period of time has this swelling increased, of course bowel movements [they all love to talk bowel movements don't they?], and your activity level compared to last week. I hope that you get some answers. Holiday weekends are so hard when you are scared. Everyone who is anyone, except us, is having a holiday. Hang in there, *susan*

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2011 06:42AM susan_02143 wrote: Susan, We have just been talking about Faslodex and timelines in another thread. If you respond positively to this drug, there is a pretty good shot at getting a long run. I am at 17 months, someone else is at 3+ years.... but there are those that don't respond to this drug at all. It will take you a few months to know which category you will be in. Deciding to leave a job is such a personal decision. I, for one, keep working. I need the income. Others swear by leaving their jobs and "enjoying" life. For the most part, they have better insurance programs than I do. I do believe that making any major life decision right after getting traumatic news can be a mistake. Let the dust settle and then decide what is best for you and your family. All the best, *susan*

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2010 02:51PM susan_02143 wrote: Frankie, You aren't checking the tumors per se. The tumor markers are a blood test. I get my bloods drawn monthly and the oncologist orders two tests, CEA which is a general cancer test, and the CA27.29 which is specifically for breast cancer. Doing the test once will not do much for you however. The power of these tests is your specific trends. So using me as an example. I had my first markers done right after surgery, and then every 3 or 6 months from then on. When my numbers started to rise, I started getting scans. My numbers actually more than doubled before the scans could confirm that I had metastic activity. So, for me, my tumor markers show progression before scans. But, other women see absolutely no movement regardless of their tumor's activity. I guess that my caution is, if you pay for this test out of pocket you will need to continue to do this in order to get anything meaningful from the numbers. One time will not be sufficient. Hope this wasn't too long and perhaps, even a little helpful. *susan*

Posts.Content: May 24, 2010 08:06PM susan_02143 wrote: English, I have spent several hours thinking about your workplace and this really unpleasant interaction between you and your subordinate. As someone who has managed many employees [and will never ever ever ever do that again!], perhaps I can offer another perspective. Your original post actually has two competing components. The first is professional. This person works for you, she is undermining your authority with vendors, and is working at odds to the goals of your department. To me, it feels like she has found an opportunity to assert herself as the "real" leader and worker. I suspect that she hopes when you fail and/or don't return to work, her job will be safe. Further, she may very well be thinking "if there are layoffs, maybe English will go and I will be the one kept." And finally, she got caught and is not willing to vocalize that she knows what she did was unprofessional and has given you, her supervisor, no assurance that this will not happen again. The second thing I hear in your post is that your feelings are hurt. Co-worker doesn't send cards, doesn't sympathize regarding your cancer and treatment options. Unsaid, but I suspect she doesn't want to hear about your latest doctors appointments. And as you say, she doesn't even "wish you well." I fear that you are mixing personal with professional. There is no requirement in a work environment that co-workers be anything beyond a co-worker. Cards, wishes, group lunches and all the trappings of "faux friendships" sometimes work their way into the business world, but we can't demand that our co-workers treat us the way we treat them if it crosses out of the business relationship. This person sounds really unpleasant. I would HATE to work with her on a regular basis, but I wonder if you removed your hurt feelings from the equation if you would be able to find the appropriate response. Is discussing internal workflow with a vendor breaking a company policy?  Is is standard to have a subordinate resist correction and refuse to comply with your directives? Is there something here that would allow you to write a small warning letter that became part of her employee file? In terms of being pro-active going forward, have you considered a work board where all projects [or whatever you guys do] are mounted on a board, color coded by person responsible, date due and then date submitted? [Yea, I am just a tad evil with passive aggressive people!] I hope that you accept this post in the spirit in which it was written. What a lousy thing to be dealing with. You have reminded me why I run my own company and have zero employees. All the best and take care. *susan*

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2014 05:48AM susan_02143 wrote: Leah's caution about keeping your drugs in your carry-on is really an important one. And, you should do this going BOTH ways even though you have more drugs at home. One day, we left Marseille and flew to Paris, then it was onto a plane from Paris headed to Boston. Only, it was Sept 11th, 2001, and that plane never left. We sat on the tarmac for hours before being directed to get off the plane and leave the airport. My husband had put his drugs under the plane, and of course, that was the one bag that we couldn't find in the chaos that day. He just assumed that if the bag was lost, we would be home where he had the rest of his re's. We were lucky. My cousin Henri went with us to a pharmacy in Paris, and we were able to get what my husband needed. It was 8 days before we were able to go home. Without Henri, I have no idea what we would have done. *susan*

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2012 08:49AM susan_02143 wrote: Lynn, I use percentages to create graphs of my tumor markers. A change of more than 15% gets my attention. I also chart changes over time; i.e. three month blocks. Based on my history, anything below 70 is good. Over 100, and I know I am having a progression. The mean number isn't that interesting in isolation. This all assumes you know what your "normal" number is of course. I now have two.... I was a 44 for the years following my original DX. Now my baseline is between 68-72. I have taken this to mean, my body is always fighting these mutant cells now but with the help of Faslodex is fighting them back. As I have noted before, my numbers have consistently gone up in the Spring time. I don't know if this is due to pollen, warmer weather, or that everything wants to grow during the Spring. However, both my original dx and mets progressions were in May. Wait until month before being overly concerned. Easier said than done. *susan*

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2013 07:05PM susan_02143 wrote: Caryn, I bet your medical records would say date-x; Stage II, and then date-x_plus-2-months; Mets to Bone. So, yea, you are like me [probably.] Interesting that you started this discussion looking for precise terminology and here we are. The difference between Stage II and Stage IV is more about how much treatment you probably have had before progression. It probably means you have already had surgery, chemo and perhaps radiation. The differences are not that great. The difference between lung cancer and lung mets is huge. Things to think about. *susan*

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2010 07:30PM susan_02143 wrote: I don't often have the impulse to call someone "sweetie" on a public board, but your post has me this close | | ! You have NOT done a single thing wrong. In fact, you have done everything right. You go to your doctor, you let them dose you with pills and potions tolerating the side effects, you let them draw blood to test your markers, and you show up when the schedule scans. You are not hiding in the sand, hoping it will go away. [Okay, you might be doing that, but you are doing it in addition to taking advantage of modern medicine.] I sure thought that scans trumped blood markers, but of course your doctor knows you and your test results better than I ever will. Sending good thoughts, *susan*

Posts.Content: May 10, 2012 02:58AM susan_02143 wrote: Telling is a very personal decision. After I progressed I told my husband, daughter and two friends [neither of whom live anywhere near me.] After 10 months, I told my mother and sisters. I was forced to tell another friend recently since he wanted to compose a piece for me to play at a music festival in 5 years. Felt he needed to understand that an understudy would be required! I have recently made two friends from this site, who I do see in-real-life, and obviously they know as well. My daughter has been dating a young man for two years, so eventually he needed to understand why I went to the hospital so often. Of the original two friends, one has disappeared. So all told, exactly 9 people know that I have progressed. There will come a day when I can't hide it anymore. There will be some close friends that will be very upset that they didn't know sooner, however, this is the choice that I made and I am still confident that it is the right choice for me. *susan*

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2011 03:41PM susan_02143 wrote: Marybe, As I have fallen down into the labrynth that is the medical system, I find myself protecting myself more and more. Can't get my vein on the first try, get someone else. Don't bother to read my file before my first appointment, move on. In your case, it is harder since you have a real connection with your "home" onc, and for good reason, believe that you have done well under his care. But, just because he was the right doctor last year doesn't actually mean he is the best one for the next. If possible, take the emotion out of the equation. Where should you be treated based on how you are doing right now. Hard choices... and only you can make them. Good luck! *susan*

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2012 09:38AM susan_02143 wrote: Lauren, I always get the first appointment of the day, so my restrictions are different than later times. Until this time, I had to drink two bottles of high fat nastiness. This year, my restrictions began at the "evening" meal. Then at least 3 hrs before the scan, I had to eat another high fat meal. They check blood sugars before injecting the radiation stuff. Too many people were cheating and getting false results. This test is too expensive for that kind of crap! My machine is the latest generation. Perhaps the sensitivity of the machine matters? I follow my instructions to the letter. This test is so important to understanding what my cancer is up to to fool around. But if you don't get instructions like mine, just means you had a different protocol. *susan*

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 12:50PM susan_02143 wrote: Windy, Not sure that our fears are lessened by time, but we all get past what I affectionately called "my hysterical time." And you are not yet at a place where you can look forward. You are still waiting for your final diagnosis. For me, it was a 6 month period where my brain was really clutter with cancer/negative thoughts. For me, it got better when I had a treatment plan, and then when that treatment began to work. The fact of the matter was, the world didn't stop because I was full of fear. I still had to make food, clean the house, make a living, worry about my daughter, in other words, there was a life that I needed to be living. By paying attention to that, I was able to move emotionally to a place where the fact that I have cancer in my body, no longer is the only thing going on inside my head. There is no getting away from the fact that Stage IV sucks. It is scary. But I think you will find that this board has a vibrant and alive group of women and men who will support you as you regain your balance. Bet, *susan*

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2012 09:45AM susan_02143 wrote: The only thing that cancer has taught me is, not to be judgemental. Sometimes it is really hard, but the fact of the matter is, none of us know what is going on with someone else's life. That woman walking down the street that looks so healthy could be taking care of an abusive parent, or her sister has ovarian cancer, or she lost a child at the age of 3. I suppose that the "community" part of this website can start to feel warm and like a home. I didn't join here until after my surgery [at Stage II] since it made no sense to become involved until I knew my pathology. Several of my September 2005 chemo buddies progressed so I stayed to support them. Just as I was moving on, the crap came back and here I am. I actually think that some of the posters who are so darn sure that they know EVERYTHING about EVERYTHING are far more dangerous. Life is short. We do the best we can. *susan*

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2011 10:25PM susan_02143 wrote: Tina, So sorry to welcome you to our "club." Tomorrow, I will be receiving my 14th Faslodex injections. These injections have gotten me to NED [no evidence of disease.] Most women receive the shots while standing up, well slightly hunched over. LowRider has a great description of the "position" in the Hormonal thread that is stuck at the top of the forum. Given some traumas in my life, I get mine while lying on a bed. Make sure that the Faslodex is at room temperature before they inject. Do what you can to relax while the injection is being given. They do have to push hard to get the Faslodex into your buttocks. Chances are you will get a double dose which means one in each cheek. One of my coping mechanisms [in all kinds of things] is to count. Generally, each injection takes about 64 seconds. Each of us experience this injection differently. Side effects also vary. Overall I have found this drug to be very tolerable. Again, if you read through the hormonal thread you will see what various folks have experienced. Since this is your first treatment, I bet you don't experience much in the way of SE's. Good luck, *susan*

Posts.Content: May 29, 2015 06:21PM susan_02143 wrote: What a difference a few years makes. I have received hate PM's in the past when I posted that I kept my progression to myself for my own reasons. I didn't even tell my mother or sisters for 18 months. At this point, I have told exactly 12 people, and 6 of those were only because I thought I was going back to chemo this week. This is a personal choice, and all choices are ours to make. And all of our choices are right. When I need help. When I actually get sick. When the world needs to know, then, and only then, I will expand my circle of people who know. Tell the people that you want to know. Don't tell all those other people. Do what feels right for you, now. You can always change your mind to expand the circle. You can't ever make that circle smaller. *susan*
Posts.Title: Telling (or not telling) friends and family ABeautifulSunset steelrose

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2011 08:10AM susan_02143 wrote: I have never had employer-sponsored health care, so I have been picking health care plans since I was 17 years old. I admit that I simply didn't buy health insurance between the ages of 18-21. It was all I could do to pay for my college tuition during those years, even working full-time. For many years, we bought what would now be considered catastrophic insurance. Very high deductible. However, with the arrival of baby in 1986, we started reviewing other options. [Kids are expensive!] Every year, we reviewed our options and chose the plan that seemed to fit our needs. Moving back to the Northeast allowed us to use non-profit insurance companies. Until last year, we chose a plan with no RX coverage since our monthly RX bills were exactly $12.30. However, with my progression, a change in the MA law, and a quick review of how much Xeloda would cost should I progress, this year we opted for much better RX insurance. I belong to a business association which means we are in the market as part of a much larger group so that my health history isn't part of the insurance cost calculation. All we can do it make the best decision based on our current circumstances, along with some knowlege of what our future will bring. *susan*

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2008 08:32PM susan_02143 wrote: old, It does get better, especially since you don't define yourself by your cleavage. Over time, some of the breast regroups and fills in a bit. I am now three years out, and I suspect what I have is what I get, and it isn't perfect, but it isn't bad. For me, it wasn't actually the cosmetic stuff, but what the cosmetic stuff represents. This "stuff" forced me to face mortality, consider my kid growing older without me, and my husband watching me get reallly sick. Be kind to yourself. Don't use a mirror if it makes you sad. Move forward by doing the things that reinforce your own value to yourself. And take comfort with the thousands of women who post on this site every day. Be well, *susan*

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2012 11:38AM susan_02143 wrote: A few thoughts: 1. To be honest, these doctors make SO much more money that I do, I have never considered giving a gift with monetary value. I have given my radiation techies small gifts, but that is different. What I have done is write a letter to the department head detailing the exceptional care I believe I have received. These letters are then slipped into their personell file and can make a difference when there is a possible promotion. 2. Dana was not at all open to directing chemo at local facilities when my sister was treated there. But breast cancer is a different animal for early stages. The protocols are quite standardized so broaching the subject is how you will find out the anwer. Worse thing they can say is no and then you can decide if you want the Lahey to be your primary oncologist. Hope this helps. *susan*

Posts.Content: susan_02143 wrote: For the past few nights I have had a really weird, yet surreal dream. There is a stage with three curtains. The stage is straight out of "Name that Price" or whatever that old show was called. The curtains have way too many pleats and there are spotlights swirling around lighting the space. An excited voice says "And behind door No 1 is surgery. We will remove your breast and you will take months to recover. Or we have Door No 2. Chemo that will make you bald and sick again. And finally, Door No 3, you will get a new aromatese inhibitor." The voice sounds excited, like I am winning a trip to Tuscany, or a week in Paris. In my dream, my mind is a running commentary, trying to analyze the options as they are presented. A Vanna White wanna-be is in a gold lamé dress, her arms gracefully pointing to each curtain as the choices are announced. Today I met with my Oncologist, Dr. Roger, to review my scan results and talk about the treatment options. Today's meeting included no gold lamé I am happy to say. Just two white coats, my husband and myself. Dr. Roger was clearly relieved that there were no bone mets. [If there had been he was planning some really heavy guns! An interesting aside.] He sees mets along the chest wall [where my original tumor was attached] going vertically, and one on the outside of the lung [not a lung met.] He confirmed what I had heard during my conversation with the PA. Minimal. He then began to draw pictures. [Dr. Roger likes to draw pictures, but they are really not very good.] He explained that the estrogen expression is actually two distinct expressions [alpha and beta, scientists are sooooo boring.] The aromasin blocks one of them while the other expression, which is rarer, is left alone. Surprisingly, Dr. Roger is continuing the aromasin, but adding Faslodex to block the second expression. Since my blood markers have been an accurate look into my progression, we will start testing these monthly, at the same time as my injection. I will see Dr. Roger again in two months, unless next month's markers continue the rise. I was then taken to the chemo infusion room. My former chemo nurse, Nurse Judy, gave me the Faslodex injection in the same chair that used to be my A/C spot. Damn what a large needle! I counted to 63 seconds, but it is possible I was counting really fast. There is no dignity to cancer. The irony is, the awful pain I have been experiencing, the pain that started the search is completely unrelated to my progression. Instead I have to have my gallbladder removed! Now that I know the plan, I have lots of questions/thoughts, but that will be a different post.   *susan*  anotherplan.blogspot.com... and its back. May 3, 2010 mets found. Five years NED on Faslodex * 4/2015 progression to bone * 6/11/2015 Femara/Ibrance * 12/27/2015 Xeloda * 2/24/2016 Xgeva * another progression, another drug Taxol 2/14/2017 Dx 6/8/2005, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIB, Grade 1, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2013 06:07AM susan_02143 wrote: One of the first things I learned on this journey was, the minute a doctor saw cancer on my charts, EVERYTHING was cancer. It is almost like the rest of our body ceases to exist, and doctors are simply incapable of looking at the whole picture anymore. Several studies have been done about this, showing that most doctors, even ones that know us well, decide within the first 30 second of our visit what "angle" they will pursue. So, I complained about some pain near my right rib [the affected side] and darn primary determined it was breast cancer returning. Never looked farther. It was CANCER. In fact, sometimes it is a gallbladder which by the time it was diagnosed correctly, was an emergency surgery. ER docs do the best they can, but they may or may not be right. *susan*

Posts.Content: susan_02143 wrote: With this week's confirmation of mets, I find myself part of the Stage IV community. So instead of crashing the party, I will formally introduce myself. I found my lump 4 years and 51 weeks ago. Given my tumor's personality, I received the standard protocol: partial mascetomy, 4 rounds of A/C, 33 rads plus 8 boosters. I have been in a study of Armidex vs Aromasin since December 15,2005. I was just about to open my last bottle of the aromasin and was really counting down the days when I could say good-bye to all the side effects. Of course, standard protocol would have included 4 rounds of Taxol, but given my low rish of recurrance and because I play the violin professionally, my medical team chose to omit it. The neuropathy caused by Taxol would have comprimised my fine motor coordination. I have not yet had a meeting with my Oncologist, but received the news via phone from his physician's assistant. She catagorized the results as 'minimal' with mets showing in my chest cavity and lymphs in the upper right quadriant of my body. Bone scans and MRI's didn't show any bone activity. I am married, same guy for 27 years, have a 24 year old daughter and am self-employed. I am a business consultant and database developer now, but still play the violin professionally as often as possible. We live in a house with bad water karma just outside of Boston, and groan when it rains and is windy at the same time. We have a cat that doesn't know that at 16 years old it should be getting old, and acts more like a dog every year. I am cynical, have a well-honed cancer humor, generous, caring, and don't take fools lightly. I love laughter, but don't do that enough, and having happy people around my dinner table, which I am doing more of lately. I am petrified about the finances of this diagnosis. Oh, not today. Nothing has changed today, but the future. I worry about who will take care of my husband when his genetic Alzeihmers starts. And then I remind myself, that this is a long term chronic condition, and I will not need to make some of these big choices until there is progression. anotherplan.blogspot.com... and its back. May 3, 2010 mets found. Five years NED on Faslodex * 4/2015 progression to bone * 6/11/2015 Femara/Ibrance * 12/27/2015 Xeloda * 2/24/2016 Xgeva * another progression, another drug Taxol 2/14/2017 Dx 6/8/2005, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIB, Grade 1, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2018 01:32AM susan_02143 wrote: On Sunday, I was going to write a chipper post about how much easier cycle 3 was for me. That was Sunday. So let me review. The foot and hand neuropathy has gotten worse for sure. I was rather astonished when was going out that I could no longer "feel" my sandals and slip them on. Instead, I had to watch my feet and direct them with my brain. Digestive system is behaving, though if I eat too much in one sitting I get acid reflux. As a result, i am disappearing a bit. (Very odd feeling for someone who has always been a little too big.) I still have hair, and in fact, might need a trim soon. Energy levels have been fine. And then yesterday, clearly my blood counts tanked. I am so tired. I have a terrible headache. I actually had a coke today [Mexican] hoping that the caffeine and sugar would help. It might have. Or maybe a protein-heavy dinner [small as it was] is helping. I am finding hot weather really wearing on this drug. Is this true for others? SouthernSurvivor, none of my mets are in a location that a biopsy wouldn't have potential significant issues, so we keep treating what I had back in 2005. The research nurse on my current clinical trial tried to convince my oncologist to biopsy and got absolutely no where! IrishTwin, I hope that your sister's off-week is going well and that her white blood counts are holding up well. Lulubee, need to hear from you. You are in the middle of cycle 1 which I found to be quite hard and had me doubting my reasons for living! Please check in. Kris, I have never heard of half the drugs you are taking to manage side-effects but am way too fatigued to do the research right now. It has been a "day or two." Any improvement? *susan*

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2018 11:36AM susan_02143 wrote: Today was cycle 5, week 2. I had a different research nurse today, with different suggestions about my side effects. But first, I made several people laugh! I mentioned that I had had a fever last Wednesday. It reached the magic 100.4 level, and I explained that though I had been told to call or come in at that temp, I have a different rule. My fever must remain at that level for at least 3 hours before I will even consider a trip to the ER. That made them all laugh, and then they all agreed that it wasn't a bad rule. Anyhow, this nurse suggested taking Magnesium and Vitamin B Complex pills for the cramping in my large leg muscles and hands. Has anyone tried that? As I listed my side effects, she kept jotting down notes. She then looked up and said, "Wow. You are getting all the rare, but documented side effects." Lucky Me. New routine at the hospital today. If you agree to a flu shot, you no longer have to go to another floor and wait in line. The shot is sent to your infusion nurse and given as you finish treatment. I always forget how sore the injection site is after a flu shot. So, overal, I am doing okay. Oh, one other thing. Research nurse allowed how there is one more possible dose reduction possible and still stay on this trial. *susan*
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2018 01:04PM susan_02143 wrote: Today was day one of cycle 6. I am settling into the "this is my life" phase of treatment. My biggest side effect is the night (mostly) leg and hand cramps. Stretching out my legs before bed does actually help. Until about 4:30am, and then shifting my position can trigger a really nasty cramps. These cramps can make me cry. A friend suggested walking it off. That landed me on the floor. Not going to do that again! I will have scans at the end of this cycle, and we shall see how I am doing. Kimchee. How are you doing so far? Susan
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2018 01:55PM susan_02143 wrote: Hi Mzmerz, Been a long time since I have seen your name. Good to see you once again. My hair thinned [it was already pretty thinned from Taxol] but I actually had to pay someone to cut it this week. How annoying. I don't really have money for hair stuff these days. The muscle cramps are my biggest complaint on this drug. On day 4/5 and 11/12 are the worst for energy. I have headaches [and have run out of Advil! Ack!] Tonight, I am running a fever. Is this the precursor to being sick or a side effect of chemo? I have no idea. I am watching this closely, but going to the ER in a major city on a Friday night is about the last thing I want to do. Tuesday through Friday, I am starving and have learned to eat as much as possible. Then my appetite wanes and the pounds start to come off. I try really hard on Monday to eat LOTS of calories so that no one on my medical team notices. But, note above, money is getting tight, so my go-to take outs are really not an option. I love to eat Massaman curry on Mondays but Mr. 02143 doesn't like this dish. I simply refuse to make two different meals. The off week is a bit of a disappointment. When I was on Taxol, there was a great curve upwards for the entire week. On this drug, I sit at the bottom for longer and don't feel that I get the rebound as quickly as I would like. This is what I have energy to report tonight. Have questions? Please ask. I will do my best to help you out. p.s. oh the neuropathy and dropped foot! forgot to mention those!
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2018 08:19AM susan_02143 wrote: KPW, I think it was around cycle 3 that I started to notice that my left foot didn't always "go" with the leg. I haven't done anything about it, though I have certainly reported this to the clinical trial nurse. My strategy has been to always pay attention when I am on the move to ensure that this foot doesn't get caught on a wire, or area rug, or the kitchen island. I do think, non-scientifically, that the stretches that I am doing for the cramps has helped a bit. I think Dana Farber categorizes dropped foot as a "strain" of neuropathy. Because having one kind of neuropathy isn't enough! i know that I have had at least four different versions over the past two years. Would love to hear about the exercises suggested by your PT.

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2018 06:07AM susan_02143 wrote: Began Cycle 2 today. Same routine as always. Donate tons of blood to the LabGods, wait. Meet with the doctor along with the research nurse and discuss how I feel. One of my weirdest side effects occurred during day 18-20. I had several episodes when I simply had to "pee" NOW. Not in a few minutes. Not in a minute. Now. The looks on their faces as I told me about this was not good. Neuropathy of the bladder. Really? This is a thing? And I am one of the lucky people to have this rare side effect? Other side effect that concerns them is my "weak in the knees" feeling. But the blood work looked good, and I went back to the waiting room and waited and waited for my three-minute treatment. On the way home, I had to buy a bottle of shampoo! I thought I had a lifetime supply!

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2018 12:28AM susan_02143 wrote: Today is the beginning of my "off" week, cycle 2. This cycle has been far more tolerable. Some fatigue, but not every day. Neuropathy in my feet is slowing changing to Eribulin based, not Taxol, instead of both together. Fingers are getting numb spots now as well. Hair tufting has simply stopped with no bald spots. My gastric issues are not bad. The worst side effect is heartburn, something I have only had while pregnant 31 years ago. I still have a "loss of appetite" but am able to eat, just have trouble deciding what I want to eat. Mr. 02143 does have preferences, so we eat what he desires. That works well enough. My daughter will defend her doctoral dissertation this Friday, a HUGE milestone. So pleased that I can attend during a pretty good week.

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2008 02:27AM - edited Sep 2, 2008 02:29AM by susan_02143 Deb, My sister had terrible nauseau, and since her tongue is being zapped, vomiting is simply not an option [she could choke.] She gets Emend [via IV] twice a week along with her Aloxi infusion. At the same time they do a lot of hydrating. Different chemo drugs, different cancer, but maybe this would work for you as well? *susan* p.s. I want to add that during her 1991 cancer battle compazine and zofran eliminated her nauseau, and now they make it worse. My point is that a drug that worked for you once, might not work now. Our bodies adapt, and our cancer changes.

Posts.Title: Update on Jenny66 lwd katie11

Posts.Content: May 19, 2015 09:01PM susan_02143 wrote: Everything you ever thought about Ebru is true. She is smart, beautiful, funny, caring, and full of a spirit that shines through on every level. Had we ever been together before? No. And yet, it was a day where we felt that we were lifelong friends, just restarting our conversations. We laughed, and talked, and laughed some more, and had conversations that had depth and meaning. My husband and I jumped on the Metro and headed to the stop that Ebru had given us and she picked us up in her sporty VW. We were off to a "typical" Istanbul coffee shop, but somehow, the plan changed and we changed direction. Over the second bridge to a palace in Asia; a real sultan's palace overlooking the Bosphorous that has been converted to a restaurant and event center. We walked up the front stairs [marble of course] and began to look around. It was empty of people so we went up the second set of stairs and found ourselves in the most glorious foyer. Still no people, so we kept walking,through a huge ballroom with crystal chandeliers, and into a large parlor with frescoes on the ceiling. We found fancy bathrooms, but no people. It was like visiting a museum without any guards. We found a terrace, but it had workers and no restaurant. Finally, down some stairs and we found the restaurant, on a terrace with the straights down below. We had a lovely lunch. Ebru chose three meze: hummus, a roasted pepper, tomato and walnut salad, and fried bulgher meatballs. For an entree, Ebru and my husband chose the tandoori lamb shanks and I tried the veal koftas. We each had some side dishes that included a special spiced rice, eggplant served different ways, and the obligatory grilled pepper. All perfectly prepared and did I mention the view? In the garden beneath the terrace there were two peacocks, very vocal peacocks giving another atmospheric touch! After coffee it was time to leave. I think we were all getting a little fatigued and so we went back inside and found the door to leave. But! Someone came after us because we were in the kitchen! What a kitchen! It was huge with so many different stations. It was a small crew for this meal service, but clearly they can prepare food down there for at least 2000 people. The mixer was bigger than some bathtubs! Someone showed us out a side, employee entrance. So fun to see so many parts of the palace that were not supposed to be on the tour. Perhaps a few signs would be helpful for future guests? Can you imagine how hard we laughed as we remembered being able to thank the chef for a lovely meal? We arrived back at our hotel around 6pm, full and happy. We had such a lovely time with Ebru. I only wish we were here a little longer so we could enjoy each other's company some more. *susan*

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2018 11:25AM susan_02143 wrote: Jennifer, I actually understand [intellectually] that I am very lucky that my clot was found via scan. Since I am being scanned so regularly with this clinical trial, we know that this small clot didn't exist 12 weeks ago. Useful knowledge, I would think. While talking with Dr. C, she used many of the same logical explanations regarding "no pills." She also added that this injectable drug is the only one which has been tested with good results in "our population." She also mentioned that warfarin requires that you eat exactly the same nutritional content each day and that this is not easy for "our population." Cancer patients, the logic goes, have too many outside influences on their taste buds and energy levels to eat the exact same amount of vitamins, especially Vitamin K, each and every day. This injectable drug, since it is dosed by weight, is more accurate. As to the needles, I am one tough woman except for this one thing. Mr. 02143 isn't doing a great job, but at least he is doing it. Oh, and I am so sorry that you are having to do these injections as well. Lulu, if you are anything like me, cycle 2 will be easier. My port has never been right. It has failed to give blood five times, though the first four times we did all kind of weird positioning and simply waiting, and it did finally give the goods. Three times, the port was so inflamed that no one would access it. The Taxol burned, and the port pain would last most of the week, hurting me and causing enough itching to wake me in the middle of the night. I am just about done with my week off. But you must be starting yours? I am so glad to hear that the barium/contrast combination makes other feels nasty. At least it is normal. *susan*

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2018 09:17PM susan_02143 wrote: I can live with this. Another good day yesterday. I was careful, however, not to overdo since I know that my "bad" days are coming. I made lunch. A lovely chicken salad with homemade rolls [from the magic freezer.] In the morning, I made some tart dough, later I rolled, chilled, and then made a French tomato-mustard tart for dinner served with a green salad. I feel like I had a day that resembled normal life. https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1015578-gerard..., I cooked from the book and did the tomato version. First Advil was at 10:38AM. I took a nap. I will be tired today, but I always am on Friday since I get about 90 minutes less sleep so that I am up and ready for the grand kid to arrive at 7:30. Half is going to become a Santa Fe Carne Adovada, a dish I had for the first time a year ago when visiting a friend in that city. The rest will become two different versions of breakfast sausage. I am in a search for a decent breakfast sausage formula. Sometimes, I just want a bit of breakfast sausage, and if I had patties made in the magic freezer, it would be simple to satisfy that craving. In fact, restocking the magic freezer is one of my goals. I need to make some breads, stocks, stews, and perhaps a casserole or two. One of my major goals is to put on a few more pounds. I was given the "lecture" again this week. I had to take a 20 minute nap around 2pm, but it was so pleasant, I chose to extend it another 20 minutes. That felt luxurious! *susan*

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2018 11:27AM susan_02143 wrote: Gathering some extra energy to report, and respond to Lulubee. I am on day 16 of cycle 6. Scans are tomorrow. Blood work is looking fine; well except for those tumor markers. I had had a steady drop during the first five cycles, but this cycle, week 1, they were back to where we started. Not promising to be honest. Tumor markers, especially 27.29 and now the 15-3, have been very accurate for me in the past. The CEA has not, but even that one has shot up to the highest level in years. If history repeats, tomorrow's scan won't show a progression. The tumor markers go up about 2-3 months before the scans see the uptick. Damn! So yes, I have scans tomorrow. Due to the trial I am on, it is a CT which I detest. I am not loving this drug, to be honest. As Lulubee mentions above, the cramps are fierce! My trial nurse has stated that they can not be controlled through diet. She has hopes for a topical cream but none of her patients can afford the cream, so she has read the results but doesn't have first hand notations. She has suggested that I do leg stretches before bed and that does help. I have added arm stretches too. But how do you stretch your neck/jaw? And I can't stretch my hands in an effective manner. I am getting what they call trigger finger which is really scary. There you are, slicing garlic thinly and suddenly your hand is clenched and unusable. I have learned how to wake as a cramp begins and work to reduce the intensity. There is a price for that though. Other muscles in my body seem to absorb the tension, and I am simply not getting solid blocks of sleep. Neuropathy continues to be an issue in my feet as well. For the first time, I used my handicap placard in a parking lot since I just couldn't imagine walking from the other spots. Does anyone else feel that their arms are getting weaker? Lifting a king duvet is really hard for me these days, and I don't recall that being a problem in the past. Getting that same bloody duvet into a duvet cover is like doing pull-ups. I am not needing stool softeners. The headaches still exist but don't have the same intensity and I can often go several days without an Advil. My commitment to helping out my daughter and son-in-law with their kid's childcare and preschool delivery has increased dramatically. We now get up at 6:15 every day [early for me] except on chemo days when I have to get up around 5sm. I am making her breakfast four days a week, same with lunch and snack. Some days she carries her lunch to school; others we are at home. Good thing I like her! Cycle 7, assuming the scans are stable, should begin on Tuesday. I plan to enjoy these few "good" days before then as much as possible. Susan

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2018 10:47AM susan_02143 wrote: I am just going to jump in.... I tried to read this entire thread... but all those names. Those names that I remember so very well, who are no longer with us. I simply couldn't. I moved away from these boards last August; needed to have some separation, but new progression, new protocol. It is time for me to see if there is still a place for me here. I have been doing this for a long time. I am lucky. I am still here. But, with each new drug, it becomes harder and they say I still have a Low Tumor Load!!! I can only imagine what a High Tumor Load might be. I am actually taking the Eribulin as part of a Phase II study. Since I was randomized into the B arm, I am not getting the Pembrolizumab. I started Cycle 1 on Tuesday. Day 2 and 3 were normal, but I woke at midnight in great pain. Upper abdomen felt like it was being pulled like a rubber band, while my ribs throbbed. Never felt anything like it before. I do have tumors in that rib, so perhaps it was a flare? Maybe someone kicked me and I didn't notice? I have no idea. Otherwise, my digestive system is trying to find its new normal. My neuropathy in my feet has chanced, and I am adding the palms of my hands. Tomorrow morning I will do it again. Any tips appreciated, of course.

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2018 04:06AM susan_02143 wrote: Today began cycle 4. White blood counts are a tad low; certainly low for me, but onward. Most of my doctor visit was talking about blood thinners. 6-12 MONTHS.... maybe indefinitely!!!!! My new life is one of a pin cushion. Then we reviewed my eribulin side effects. The level of neuropathy is now grade 2 and they have, indeed reduced my dose. The research nurse was a bit snotty "this is very early for a reduction" but she isn't living in my body. I am very comfortable with this dose. I know at my old hospital that my low dose is their starting dose. The actual push was quick and easy. The minute that first drop hit my system, the headache was back. Thank goodness I can control it with Advil. However, my feet and fingers are not responding as quickly as the last treatment which is great. *susan*
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2018 10:36PM susan_02143 wrote: Lulu, No. I didn't ice. I can't find anyone at my hospital that thinks icing helps so no support system exists for this. [They do have cold caps for people who are willing to pay BIG for them. I have to say, I find the moans of pain from those patients disconcerting and would prefer not to hear them.] Last night, my feet tingled a bit, but nothing like cycle 3 where I went numb within 3 hours of the infusion. My fingertips are not screaming in pain as I type this which was also the case during cycle 3. Sorry about the Taxol fluff. Mine has simply remained on my head. In fact, it is time to ask my daughter to trim it up again. I ate too much at dinner last night [husband insisted on eating out] and had to take a Zantac. Probably worth not loosing another pound. For those that are interested, full dose was 1.4 mlg/M2 [squared]. I am now getting 1.1 mlg/M2 [squared.] *susan* p.s. yes vote on the tequila!
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2018 11:07PM susan_02143 wrote: Sheila, I will try to answer your question "Can I ask what changed?" but it turns out that this simple question is hard to answer. First off, my problem has never been pain. I have not had any pain from my tumors since the breast tumor was removed in 2005. Oh, I have some neuropathic pain, but that has only made some walking, like from the edge of a parking lot to a store, problematic. During my 5 years of Faslodex, my butt hurt. My stomach is starting to rebel from all these Lovonox shots. But, I do not have what I would call chronic or cancer pain. Yes, I know that I am very lucky. This winter was a hard one. Some things in my personal life got squirrely just as the toxicity of Taxol was beginning to take a toll. We changed my protocol for the Taxol to full strength, but with a 3 week on, 2 week off schedule. But those squirrely things emptied my energy and emotional reserves, and I simply could.not.do.anything. I was not tired and yet I was exhausted. I had no energy or perhaps motivation to accomplish. I hit the "wall" several times a day; a wall that made my brain stop working, much less my body. And then I had a progression. And then the Eribulin which simply did me in. I had a few days during those first 12 weeks of Eribulin that I could do anything, but for me, this wasn't enough. It took me 3 weeks to make a dress for the grand kid; a pattern that should take me about 5 hours normally. With nothing in reserve, I was paralyzed. The current dose reduction gives me some hope. My brain isn't shutting down. I am actually able to create a to-do list in the morning and accomplish at least some of the items on this list. Not always all, though my lists are really too long. I have had the energy to leave the house and go to the supermarket. I can think enough to actually write emails to friends and try to connect with people again. I realize that with each treatment I will have less stamina. But, being a total slug just isn't what I wish for myself. This dose reduction has lifted me to at least snail or maybe tortoise. I am functioning even if my daily goals are more limited than they once were. Does that begin to answer your question? *susan*
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2018 10:57AM susan_02143 wrote: Mustang, how wonderful that your blood booster was to blame for your misery. So glad that you didn't need it this week. And it sounds as though Lulu was also slammed by her blood booster. It sounds as though you are having a similar experience as me, though I am on the lower dose. I started cycle 5 yesterday. Uneventful day at a hospital that is known for great delays. I was home by 10:30. But, within moments of my push, my headache was back. Had some stomach pains for the first time. It was also the first time I ate something before the treatment. I won't do that again! Only new physical side effect I have noticed is my left hand, which can cramp up so that all the fingers are tightly agains the palm of the hand, and the fingers simply won't move. I use the skills I developed when playing violin professionally to talk my hand through relaxing. It takes a bit of time, and I don't like it at all. Otherwise, feet are pretty much the same. I continue to have large muscle cramps, mostly at night. And that left foot wants to drag. I have sent in my application to get a handicap placard for my car. I can see that there will be days that I will need it. These benchmarks are hard. *susan*

Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2018 01:19AM susan_02143 wrote: Happy Thanksgiving my Eribulin friends. I have now finished cycle 7. Over the 20 weeks that I have been on this drug, my blood pressure has steadily dropped. Each week, just a bit, but this Tuesday the research nurse declared that my blood pressure was dangerously low. When I got home I called my primary's office and scheduled an appointment for Friday. Yes, they wanted me to come in earlier but TWELVE people coming to Thanksgiving! There was no time for a doctor visit. Yesterday I had 30 whole minutes with my primary, who I really, really like. They took my blood pressure three times and it was only seriously low; not dangerous. Given my 25 lbs of weight loss over the past year and the current readings, she has taken me off all blood pressure meds. Her thought is that we find the baseline, not affected by the drugs, and then adjust from there. She did ask if low blood pressure was a side effect of Halavan, and I had to admit, I didn't know. Quick research at home, and why there it is, a rare but not serious side effect! I seem to always get all the weird ones! So, maybe, just maybe, if my blood pressure is a bit higher I will regain some of the energy that I no longer have. [Yup, always looking for the bright side.] More energy would certainly be a treat. Thanksgiving went well. For the first time ever, I asked my guests to bring food with them. I did make 9 items on the table.... and each guest brought something. It worked well. Since my sister can still not eat by mouth, I didn't have to have vegetarian versions of everything which was a huge work-reduction. I would not have had the capacity to do everything this year. The dishes are all done. I still have to wash all the linens that have cranberry and wine smudges. I am making some Kaiser rolls right now so our Turkey has some fresh bread to hang out with as a sandwich. I hope that all of you were surrounded by the people who make you happy! *susan*

Go to a cherry blossom festival in a lovely dress. Have a green tea popsicle while sitting on the grass in the sunlight and talk to him. He is an adult, and evidently a special one if you love him. Tell him your fears and even your hopes, and let it play out. Or do all of the above and forget the talk, enjoying the fact that you are loved. Just to let you know, the happy/sad thing concurrently is a sentiment that many of us share with you. Well, I do. *susan*

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2018 01:20AM susan_02143 wrote: Life has not been great around here. On Thursday, I had a CAT scan. I HATE these scans but they are required for this clinical trial. [PET Scans are my usual.] The barium and contrast play havoc on my body. For 24 hours I am just reamed out. But, the damn port wouldn't work [again!] For the first time they had to put enzymes into the port to coax out some blood. By the time we had blood, my appointment was long gone. Instead of a 90 minute stay at Dana Farber, I was there for four hours. Friday, at noon, Dr. C called. She said that she had some good news. That I am stable. The bad news? I have a blood clot in my left lung. I don't consider any of this good news. I am stable with smouldering tumors!! I had really hoped that the amount of uptake would have been less "red." The lung clot, though small, is obviously a bad turn. I asked her what could have led to such a clot, and her response was chilling– "This is a side effect of cancer and its treatment." How to treat? Oh, no simple pill by mouth for me. Nope. I have to inject myself TWICE A DAY! At first, she was this isn't urgent, but then she called back several more times and it was clear, I had to head to Dana Farber today to start this treatment. I waited for the Brazilians to check in [I have a small airBNB,] and for son-in-law to pick up the grand, and then I went, driving through Red Sox traffic. Thank goodness I had my regular nurse who was patient and calm, and told me stories of her recent trip to Greece. I have always said I could never stick anything or anyone with a needle. I am proving this with every passing day. "A side effect" of cancer? Seriously? More indignities to endure? For the first time, I am angry. I will see Dr. C on Tuesday and start to quiz her about how long I will need blood thinning drugs and how we will check the status of the blood clot. My husband is doing the injection because I can still not stick myself even though it is almost painless. I made some yeasted Blueberry rolls last night as my consolation prize.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2018 12:18PM susan_02143 wrote: There is hope. Hope has been in short supply lately. Day 2. I woke at 7:30. I spent the morning ironing the AirBNB sheets, oh right, after being injected. I turned over the AirBNB rooms. I made lunch. I drank more coffee. Finished the rooms. Stocked their breakfast. Took a 15 minute doze. Greeted new guests. Helped them determine where to get allergy drugs and dinner. Made our dinner. Roasted some chicken for tomorrow's lunch. My feet? No worse than they were before yesterday's infusion. Hands, same with one outlier spot. Oh, there was organizing my first floor so it was ready for new folks to arrive. Sorted the grandchild's stock of clothing, putting the too small into a box for storage. I only dropped one thing, a piece of foil. I washed my hands several times after touching raw chicken and i didn't feel like I was getting second degree burns. Not bad. Of course, Day 5 will be the true test of this reduced dose.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2018 10:07AM susan_02143 wrote: I promised myself that I would complete my week in review here, and have fallen behind. Day 4, Friday, should be the worst day of the week. I can't say this categorically since every day until Day 19 were just terrible in the previous cycles. It wasn't so bad! No Advil until 1:30, made lunch and dinner, did a Costco run, watched the 2 yr old grandchild for a 9 hour day [though Mr. 02143 did a lot of the heavy lifting.] I did three loads of laundry. I took a doze, could have used some real sleep, while the kid did a "pretend" nap on my office rug. At the end of the day, I did feel that I had over-done and anticipated paying the price on Saturday. Day 5. Saturday, was again, just fine. I was dragging just a bit and did take an hour long nap. More laundry. Lunch. And then I started to make some Leek-Potato soup which always takes too long with all the washing of the leeks. While I was prepping the vegetables I learned that my kid, kid-in-law, and grand were right down the street, so invited them to dinner. By the time they left I was exhausted. At some point, perhaps, I had twisted my back [?], anyhow, my upper let buttock is in some pain. Day 6: Sunday. This was all for me. Our guests checked out at 5AM and I had the entire day to myself. I pulled out an old sewing project, a winter shirt with buttons for port access and got to work. I did strip the beds, and grab the towels from the guest rooms, but only washed the towels. Day 7; Monday. I awoke to discover that my rooms were booked for today! So much of today involved getting the rooms ready while amusing that same 2-year old. Sitting at the hospital, doing almost nothing, might be a day off for me! I can not begin to describe how much better this reduction in dose has made me feel. This is a life that is worth living. I am a bit concerned about the odd muscle pain and the big and small muscle cramping that I have been experiencing this week. Odd sensations, and painful. My potassium levels are healthy so I am unsure about my plan. I will ask the team tomorrow iff this is a side effect of either Eribulin or the Lovonox. Tomorrow I will get up before the sun and let them do this to me once again. *susan*
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2018 11:55PM susan_02143 wrote: Day 10 I did too much. By 7pm, I had to move to my chair. A version of collapsing, I must say. I mustered enough energy to set up breakfast for the morning guests, but it was not easy! Day 11 I was whipped from the moment the day began. The headache was back. I wake early on Friday to care for the grand, and boy do I miss those 90 minutes of sleep! Even when I woke I could tell that my blood counts were dropping– rash a little bumpier and itchy, a mouth sore or two, generally dragginess. At 8am, the grand announced that she wanted pizza for lunch, and we hadn't even had breakfast yet. I did it. Made some dough right after oatmeal was served. Her new thing is to have quiet time on a "pretend" bed in my office while I nap. She falls asleep just as I wake up, giving me a bit of Susan-time. I slept long and hard last night. I was whipped. I think I need to scale back today and give my body some time to heal. At this point, I think it is safe to say that Thursday [Tuesday infusion] is a downward slide; Friday is the hardest energy day; Saturday is a day to rebuild. This is my off week! I really hope that I have made it through the worst of this cycle, which is infinitely better than those 9 weeks of hell I endured for cycles 1-3. Thoughts to all of you, *susan*

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2018 01:21PM susan_02143 wrote: It is time for me to update. Well, to be honest, I am overdue. Last week was week 1 of cycle 8. Tomorrow will be week 2. The foot neuropathy is a bit better. It is affecting a smaller area of my feet, but that darn left foot still gets "caught" at unexpected moments. The cramps still wake me regularly. I have found that in addition to the stretching, it is good for me to wear one or even two pairs of socks to bed. This keeps the legs warmer which seems to help. Of course, this means that I am now often too hot. A small price to pay, I guess. However, the cramps still happen and they still hurt like hell. The weaning off of Lisinopril was rather rough. But the crushing headaches have passed. At Dana Farber, post-Lisinopril, my BP was sky high. The next day at my endocrinologists office, where they take their time and do an old fashioned hand reading, it was perfect. We shall see how it reads tomorrow in the rush of a Dana Farber office. I think that the Eribulin is also affecting my overall mood. Does anyone else have moments of despondency for no particular reason? *susan*

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2011 10:12AM susan_02143 wrote: When I was a young girl, each of the children were required to have one topic to present during dinner. It could be a story from our day, or an opinion about a current event, whatever we wanted, but it couldn't really be about us. And so day after day, each of us spent time thinking about our "topic." This rule went away when my mother became involved with founding Ms. Magazine [at which point I understood that we were all being trained to be corporate wives.] However, I find myself thinking about my "topic" before going to hang out with friends. It allows me to contribute to the conversation without whining about how crappy I feel that day, or what time of day I plan my naps! Rx side effects just doesn't interest most people. I feel lucky that I am still pretty darn healthy, for a woman with mutant cells fighting to control her body, so I can still find general interest topics. When I don't have a "topic" it means I really shouldn't be around the human race. Nope.... curl up on a couch and take yet another nap. *susan*

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2011 04:39PM - edited Sep 7, 2011 04:45PM by susan_02143 So many of you getting surgery tomorrow. Astonishing! Hard to believe that it has been over six years since my partial mastectomy with SNB. I was a mess before surgery. The idea that they were going to CUT my breast horrified me. Such a sensitive part of my body, and they were going to use sharp objects! Here is the good news. This surgery was not bad at all. The underarm was more painful than the breast, which had almost no pain. Here are a few things I wish I had known.... 1. wear elastic pants and a shirt that doesn't need to go over your head to surgery since they are much easier to get on when they send you home. 2. have an "old-lady" bra that locks them down to wear after the surgery for a bit. Your breast will thank you as you go over bumps when driving 3. bring a small pillow with you to the hospital to tuck between you and the seat belt on the way home 4. get the RX for pain [which you may not even need, but insist] during the pre-op and have your waiting person get it filled while you are in the OR. 5. You will probably sleep a lot the first two days after. The first day because of the drugs, the second day because you have not been sleeping well for the last week and are tired. Put clean sheets on the bed before the surgery. Just so much nicer. I will look for your reports. May your surgeries go as well as mine did. All the best, *susan*  p.s. And of course, mourning the loss of who you were before this nastiness and your breasts as you have known them is really normal, and okay.

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2013 09:57AM susan_02143 wrote: A little research indicates that Cigna requires pre-approval of all PET scans and has implemented a system that requires the doctor to do some additional documentation for patients, like us, who need more than three. It requires more work from the radiologist and/or prescribing doctor. Furthermore, cigna has found many offsite radiology clinics have not met minimum standards. My guess is that your radiology clinic was one of these clinics and is choosing not to do the extra work required to assure you a fourth PET. This isn't new. My health insurance company now utiltizes an outside review body for all PET approvals. It is more work for my doctor, and once she had to push back. I would talk to your oncologist to see if they believe you will have a problem getting future scans. http://www.managedcaremag.com/archives/0501/0501.imaging.html *susan*

Posts.Content: May 18, 2011 07:13AM susan_02143 wrote: I have told very few people. Upon my first progression, I told my husband, daughter and two close friends who don't live anywhere near me. After 10 months, I expanded the list to include my mother and two sisters. I have given my daughter permission to tell her boyfriend, but I don't know if she has. That is it. For the time being, I am actually very healthy with the exception of these darn mutant cells. I haven't figured out an upside for this information being part of the gossip mill, so for now, I am not telling. Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2012 04:25AM susan_02143 wrote: In real life, I would be at a loss for words. The best I could do would be to stammer of "What a horrible thing to say." But in reality, this type of encounter would be a rarity at my hospital. You can say many things about people from the Boston area, but we sure understand "minding your own business" and "personal space." There would be no one near me during my blood draws. The only contact I have with other patients is in the waiting room and chit-chatting is at a minimum. In seven years, I have been addresssed three times by other patients, two of whom shared my dx and doctor. The third woman was just so very lonely. She was an older Italian woman who had had seven children and missed cooking for them and seeing them. I think she just wanted me to come to Sunday dinner. And so I chatted with her every week until, well, she wasn't there anymore. I don't understand how careless people are with their words. Weren't they taught to think before they speak? *susan*
Posts.Title: Infusion Center Moments blainejennifer Fitztwins

Posts.Content: May 23, 2017 01:00PM susan_02143 wrote: I have made it seven years working full time. Just now, it is time to stop, but not because I can't work anymore.... I just can't work as much or be as available to my clients as they need. It is ethically time to step away from working on mission critical systems. I would hold off on leaving work if you feel you can do it and the cost/benefits are in favor of staying. There is no reason to make a drastic decision. But, there is nothing wrong with determining that working full time is no longer in your best interests. I spent those 7 years saving as much money as possible so I have money to pay for health insurance for those two years before government benefits kick in [assuming there are any anymore.] It was not always easy, of course. We may have eaten a few more restaurant meals to help out. But I love my work and my clients, and loosing that part of myself isn't easy. *susan*

I know I should be overjoyed, but I am not for some reason. I am back to a 3-month checkup schedule, and will be more closely monitored than ever. Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2010 01:28PM susan_02143 wrote: Stunned. I am just reeling, and I need to write/vent/share with somebody. And my dear friends, you are that somebody. Had my "6 month" checkup today with my oncologist. Has actually been closer to 8 months since he recently had some surgery and my appointment was delayed. As usual, I went into the hospital last week for a bone density test and to draw blood. Not as usual, I didn't go online and check my numbers until this morning. OMG! My ca25.27 is up to 107! This means in the past 11 months, I have gone from 38 all the way up to 107. Of course, the traffic was awful. The drivers in the garage were nuts. The elevators were slow. And I was actually late to my appointment. [Another woman was delighted. She showed up to her appointment a week early and was able to slip in!] Dr. Roger and his PA, Lauren, went through how I have been feeling. I was told to be comprehensive in my description. To be honest, for the past three months, I haven't been feeling that great. Food tastes odd. Loss of appetite [ME? Loss of appetite.] Strange liver pains that increase when I lie down. Blah blah. "This is all so capricious" he said. You know that this is an indication of tumor activity. He said lots more, with the caveat, "but of course we never know." So now, I am waiting for the call to schedule an MRI, CT scan, ultrasounds and bone scans. The full monty. I am guessing this will all take about 2 weeks to sort out, but it doesn't feel good to not know. I will not tell anyone besides my husband that I am in cancer-limbo. Certainly, no posts on Facebook or Twitter. But I needed a place to put my fear. And this thread is simply the safest place. Good wishes please.... this is feeling kind of real.

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2011 01:12PM susan_02143 wrote: Today was the day.... to meet my new oncologist and to get my PET scan results. With a new oncologist comes a new waiting room, and new desk staff, and new volunteers. And they are all so much older! I must have been the youngest person in the waiting room by at least 20 yrs [and I am not a spring chicken!] After an endless wait [about 15 min] Nurse Lauren took me back to the room and dove right in. With a huge smile she said, "your scans look good." Of course I wanted to know how we were defining "good" and so she opened up the report. Nothing! There are many words in the report, two pages of words, but the bottom line, I am dancing with my boy NED!!!!!!!!! All three spots are gone! New oncologist will be okay. Still holding out judgement to be honest. She wants to bring me into line with a double dose of Faslodex instead of the single dose. She isn't as interested in the rest of my body as Dr. Roger, but for now I am not going to fire her. NED! Can you believe it? I am just beside myself.

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2011 08:51AM susan_02143 wrote: Martya, Sounds like you will be getting 4 rounds of Adriamacyn/Cytoxan and then 4 rounds of a Taxol. This is a standard protocol. With these "names" you can research the Chemo Threads on this site to see the wide variation of experiences that other women have had. Day 5 or 6 is the hardest one... meaning Tuesday infustion, Saturday or Sunday will be the hardest days. If you are planning to work full-time through chemo, you will want to request a Tuesday or Wednesday infusion day. The type of work you do does affect your ability to continue. People with routines at work seem to do the best. People who do problem solving have more difficulty. Many companies jostle the job responsibilities around to help people work. And some very progressive companies do sick-leave pooling so you can apply for sick time owned by others. That said, you may feel sick and be tired. You might have to take some time off, especially towards the end of treatment. Whenever possible, time your treatments so that you have your days off to recover. Go on and start freezing some easy to reheat meals. I found I had to eat about 2 oz of food every two hours to stay ahead of the nausea. Others find other things work for them. The Chemo threads on this site go back many years.... do some reading and find the strategies that have worked for others. You won't know which ones might work for you until you are already in the treatment, but knowing what options are out there can be useful. No reason to reinvent the wheel... hundreds of thousands of women have done this before you. Hope this helps, *susan*

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2011 09:44AM susan_02143 wrote: Bobbi. No. I don't. I think that all cancers are very sneaky, and far more complex than current medical knowledge can comprehend. If there comes a time that research can begin to understand the full cellular life-cycle, then perhaps a cure can be found. I do not expect this "cure" to happen during my lifetime. However, unlike so many women on this board, I am okay with that. The existence of a cure does not change my daily life. It is up to me to find meaning for my life in spite of the fact that I, unlike so many others, know what I will die of. I suspect it is comforting to use the word chronic and hope, but that isn't how I view my reality. Additionally, when/if there is a "cure" it will be preventative since that is where all the money is going. But again, I believe that it will be years and years before such a breakthrough will occur. However, I believe fully in participating in studies and trials whenever possible. I have donated tissue, blood, allowed the details of my life to be studied, am in a sister-sister study, etc. Accumulating the knowledge needed to "cure" and treat this disease, and many others, is dependent upon those of us unlucky enough to hit the jackpot to give, even though it will not help us directly. I do not want my child to ever deal with this. I do not want her children to ever deal with this. This disease is already going to take so much from them, that donating a few tumor cells doesn't feel like too much. Whew.... sorry... I think I just unloaded a lot of baggage on you. I am sorry that you are feeling down. Hope is a tenuous emotion, and comes totally from within. *susan*
