Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2010 11:27PM susan_02143 wrote: I know I am talking in an empty room, but more venting needs to be done. The blood marker retest is back, and my damn number went up another 11points in a week! PET and MRI scans are in two weeks, but the bone scan needs to wait for three weeks. They get their isotopes from a nuclear facility that is going off-line for maintenance. And so I have to wait! Trying to live near the river De-Nile. Thank goodness I have a ton of work right now. No time to live in my head.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo Sept 05 Pegk susan_02143

Posts.Content: May 7, 2010 03:35PM susan_02143 wrote: And we are off...... [I am cutting pasting here from my other posting. It will get you up-to-date.] For the past few nights I have had a really weird, yet surreal dream. There is a stage with three curtains. The stage is straight out of "Name that Price" or whatever that old show was called. The curtains have way too many pleats and there are spotlights swirling around lighting the space. An excited voice says "And behind door No 1 is surgery. We will remove your breast and you will take months to recover. Or we have Door No 2. Chemo that will make you bald and sick again. And finally, Door No 3, you will get a new aromatese inhibitor." The voice sounds excited, like I am winning a trip to Tuscany, or a week in Paris. In my dream, my mind is a running commentary, trying to analyze the options as they are presented. A Vanna White wanna-be is in a gold lamé dress, her arms gracefully pointing to each curtain as the choices are announced. Today I met with my Oncologist, Dr. Roger, to review my scan results and talk about the treatment options. Today's meeting included no gold lamé I am happy to say. Just two white coats, my husband and myself. Dr. Roger was clearly relieved that there were no bone mets. [If there had been he was planning some really heavy guns! An interesting aside.] He sees mets along the chest wall [where my original tumor was attached] going vertically, and one on the outside of the lung [not a lung met.] He confirmed what I had heard during my conversation with the PA. Minimal. He then began to draw pictures. [Dr. Roger likes to draw pictures, but they are really not very good.] He explained that the estrogen expression is actually two distinct expressions [alpha and beta, scientists are sooooo boring.] The aromasin blocks one of them while the other expression, which is rarer, is left alone. Surprisingly, Dr. Roger is continuing the aromasin, but adding Faslodex to block the second expression. Since my blood markers have been an accurate look into my progression, we will start testing these monthly, at the same time as my injection. I will see Dr. Roger again in two months, unless next month's markers continue the rise. I was then taken to the chemo infusion room. My former chemo nurse, Nurse Judy, gave me the Faslodex injection in the same chair that used to be my A/C spot. Damn what a large needle! I counted to 63 seconds, but it is possible I was counting really fast. There is no dignity to cancer. The irony is, the awful pain I have been experiencing, the pain that started the search is completely unrelated to my progression. Instead I have to have my gallbladder removed! Now that I know the plan, I have lots of questions/thoughts, but that will be a different post.

Posts.Content: May 6, 2008 10:13PM susan_02143 wrote: Liezel, Oh yes, I will indeed. Visited with my father. How quickly he has gone from a vibrant man to a small, old one. And my sister has her treatment plan. They have decided to go for a cure [ not a given ], and she will have the tumor removed from her tongue and the bottom of the mouth cavity. After the tumors have been removed, the reconstruction team will move in and rebuild using parts of her forearm, and skin from some other area. She will then move to full head/neck radiation for 7 weeks with once weekly chemo. They claim she will need a feeding tube starting at week 5, and will need ample narcotics to withstand the pain, so will be unable to drive herself to treatments. The treatment plan is about 6 months from front to back. This is all contingent upon a clean CT and PET scans scheduled for later this week. Sounds pretty rough to me, but she is sounding pretty upbeat all things considering. Be well my sisters, *susan*

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2008 11:22PM susan_02143 wrote: First food basket has been delivered. This week I included a garbanzo/ginger soup [6 servings], salmon fish cakes [based on a recipe from AlaskaDeb who is now fighting mets], meatballs, a full pound of pasta well buttered and some mango/ginger sorbet. Next week will be all soups. This is the last week my sister will be able to eat by mouth, we think. Already, the sores are taking over her mouth making swallowing difficult. With luck, we will get an additional week of some foods supplemented by her feeding tube. Happy notes: I found some more local English peas and will serve them tomorrow night with some smoked salmon and pasta. I love it when vegetables are being harvested less than 15 miles from my house. One more week, and we will be harvesting our own tomatoes. The herb garden is growing like crazy. My daughter is home andis full of life and happiness. Sandra, how are you healing??? Calico, deep breathes. We are all scared of mets and recurrance. I try not to give into that though, since that means cancer has won. Leanne, your relationship with Scott and with the boys is complicated at best. I do hope that they are managing without Scott, and enjoying being with you. *susan*

Posts.Content: May 28, 2009 11:30PM susan_02143 wrote: Tina, amazing amazing amazing!!!!! Well, we hit the four year anniversary for my lump discovery. And on that four year anniversary, my lovely daughter graduated from college. We went out to her school and spent three days. We met professors, watched the Laurel parade, and heard a lot of smart women making speeches. The kid has had several interviews for very competitive positions, but hasn't been hired for any of them. She isn't defeated. She continues to send out applications, resumes and cover letters. Hard time to be graduating and looking for a job. Sadly, my oncologist checkup at the beginning of the month didn't go so well. Though I feel fine, my numbers tell a different story. Everything is going up... tumor markers, hemaglobans and my blood oxygen levels are "of concern." We redid the tests, and they had gone up even more. We are waiting for something called the Jak2 mutation test. Oncologist is worried about my bone marrow. This test will take another 2 weeks to come back, so nothing to do but live life and push this to the back of my mind. Trying to pretend that I am not waiting for another test result as best as I can.

This is a man who lives on Denial Island. The kid starts her new job on Monday. She is nervous and excited at the same time. She continues to look at apartments and meet potential room-mates, but nothing has been just right yet. She is so ready to have her own place. And who can blame her? Headed to San Francisco for a conference in August. Husband is coming along, and we are spending a couple of extra days to do some sightseeing. I am looking forward to a trip, even if I will spend much of the time in a function room at a big hotel. *susan*

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2009 01:00AM susan_02143 wrote: Oh my! I don't "facebook" and hadn't heard about Leanne. Is she facing, or has this been confirmed? Her doctors were awfully quick to call "Stage IV" after all. Why doesn't she post here? Mostly I came here to let Nicole know that I am thinking of her often. In fact, Nicole, you hardly leave my mind. Take up a full seat, please, since you know you have grabbed the brass ring. Around here, life is good. For some reason my Onc has ordered a gazillion tests which I will begin in a week. I have a new lump in the "affected" breast, but I think it is just scar tissue that has hardened. By September 1 I will know that this is nothing. The kid LOVE LOVES LOVES her new job. LOVES LOVES LOVES her new apartment. And is learning to call before "dropping" by. My dear uncle, who I have been helping with food, etc has died. He simply didn't wake up one morning. He died in a small town, in his favorite place in the world. Services are next weekend. One of his dying wishes was that I would play at this service, so I am frantically practicing. His other dying wish was that I be allowed to select cooking utensils from his kitchen. Very sweet. Though this is all sad, it is a miracle that he was able to choose when and how he died. I admire his perseverance and determination. And I miss knowing that I can visit and enjoy his company. So that is the news from Boston. Many good thoughts as we approach our chemo-versities.... *susan*

Posts.Content: susan_02143 wrote: Edie and I met when she came to Boston with her daughters for a vacation. She asked to meet, and I reluctantly agreed. She wanted to eat at an Irish pub, and see a "real" neighborhood, and so that is what we did. I picked her up at her downtown hotel, and we headed to Inman Square to eat at a true Irish pub. I am not particularly, or even specifically Irish, but this place had some good reviews from trusted sources. Edie ordered the Shepards Pie and ate it with complete relish. Instead of being awkward, we had a great time together! Edie ordered another beer and we just talked and talked. When that beer was done, we weren't ready to leave each other so we went to a local coffeeshop and had a tea. Finally, I took her back to her hotel, having gained another friend. Ever since, we have spoken via text or phone at least once a month so I was concerned when she didn't respond to my latest text. Or the next one. Today, I took a deep breath and did the search. Edie lived a completely different life than me and yet, we found each other through this nasty disease. Her greatest concern was her youngest daughter Taylor who has just turned 17 [if my math is correct.] For those that knew and cared about Edie, here is a link to her obituary: www.legacy.com/obituaries/timesunion/obituary.aspx?page=lifestory&pid=166615979 Rest in peace Edie. *susan* anotherplan.blogspot.com... and its back. May 3, 2010 mets found. Five years NED on Faslodex * 4/2015 progression to bone * 6/11/2015 Femara/Ibrance * 12/27/2015 Xeloda * 2/24/2016 Xgeva * another progression, another drug Taxol 2/14/2017 Dx 6/8/2005, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIB, Grade 1, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2008 08:12PM susan_02143 wrote: LuAnn... this is a very effective letter, but, it will work better as a letter to the editor. Media doesn't really care about Stage IV patients. To them, BC is a marketing message full of kittens, puppies, butterflies and lovely women in long flowing skirts. And to be honest, October [my b-day month and the month I most dread each year] is really about awareness. Who are these people who aren't aware of cancer? To be most effective, edit that letter and send it to every newspaper that runs a happy BC story. Give us permission to use your shortened letter, and each of us can submit the letter to our local papers when we spot those silly articles. Today the Boston Globe had an obituary for a 43 year old, 14 year survivor of breast cancer. She got a two column spread because she created a concierge service at Beth Israel Hospital here in Boston for Oncology patients. During those 14 years, she used her energy to make life better for those that followed her. But I can guarantee you that she will not be mentioned in all the articles that will be published during October. I don't own anything with a pink ribbon...... *susan*

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2010 01:09PM susan_02143 wrote: Renee, Nope. You are not a druggie.... you are a Stage IV cancer patient that is managing her pain levels with the tools available. I read two recent Boston Globe blurbs [within the last year] that quoted two studies that show that people with pain who take pain medications don't become addicted. Our bodies process the stuff differently based on pain vs no-pain. Wish I had links to these studies, but I don't. Without pain, the ""actually look forward" could be a flag if you had no pain, but give yourself a break. Why wouldn't you look forward to not having pain? *susan*

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2013 05:14AM susan_02143 wrote: Diana, Your number alone means absolutely nothing. What is important is what is your normal number, and what is the trend. My "normal" during the four years between Stage II and Stage IV was 66. Even with no cancer activity, that is where I sat. 58, for you, might mean that there is no activity, low activity, or lots of activity. ONE test doesn't tell you anything at all. Your onc should be ashamed to throw that number at you without explaining the limitations of just one data point. *susan*

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2012 08:29PM susan_02143 wrote: Hair is a funny thing. Just read all the posts about hair on this site. I lost my hair during round 1 of this foolishness back in 2005. The hair grew in, but, I kept cutting it short. I had never had short hair and I was puzzled by my choice. One day it dawned on me- I was being superstitious! Some weird brain thing was telling me if I let it get long again, the cancer would return. Now, I am so NOT that person. I am practical to a point that annoys many folks so this was very out of character. So, after 4 yrs, I let my hair start to grow. Of course, the cancer returned after 4 1/2 years. But I don't think they are related. Currently my hair is 12 inches long. I will grow it for 2 more inches and then cut it all off for Locks of Love. A small thing to do, but somehow it makes all of this make a bit more sense to me. So, why are you emotional? Pick a reason.... there are so many to choose from. *susan*

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2007 09:11PM susan_02143 wrote: So my friends.... Tomorrow morning I am off to Los Angeles. I am going to demonstrate a new software program that I have designed/built. This is a huge step, and I was pushed by my husband. Wish me luck... but... the reason I am posting is that on my to-take list, I had written "Notebook." So I went to the notebook area of my shelves and pulled one. Next, I flipped through the notations that already existed. OMG! This was my medical journal. I sat down, and read. It started on May 1st..... and went through to the first chemo. Reading this diary was astonishing. This woman was so calm as she found her lump, and started contacting doctors. As I read each entry, each medical professional's name jumped off the page, familiar and clear. Who is this woman who journals with such detachment? Needless to say, I put this journal back on the shelf, and grabbed a different one to take to LA. I didn't cry. Maybe I have just put this susan into a box, and closed it with heavey-duty packing tape. But as I sat there, reading, the names of all my September sisters went through my head. We are slowly moving away from each other, but each of you is burned into my memory. Be well, my dear friends.... *susan*

Posts.Content: May 5, 2008 11:15PM - edited May 6, 2008 08:04AM by susan_02143 My dear September Sisters, I have read all of the postings.. but can't respond right now. Life at the susan household has really sucked. My father had open heart surgery 15 days ago to repair a valve. Turns out that my father had a heart defect from birth that only caused issues recently. The surgery was supposed to last 4-5 hours, but once they were in there, they found they had to replace the valve, and repair three others. He was on the heart/lung machine for 7 hours. He is still in ICU, and he isn't doing well. I will head there tomorrow to be with him for the first time. My mother can't be with him tomorrow because, oh god, my younger sister has been dx'ed with another cancer. She has an oral cancer most common in smokers, but she has never smoked. This is her third cancer. The first at age 28 she should not have survived... the second one was easy... this one is nasty. My internet research indicates that only 20% survive. So tomorrow, I will be with my confused, sick father while my mother and sister are at Dana Farber having their first meeting with her five new doctors. I am reeling. I alternate between total denial, and being overwhelmed. My poor mother. She has been my sister's rock.. and my father's partner.... and now she is trying to be both. Please consider sending my family your most positive thoughts as we navigate this hard reality. The good news now: in spite of my breast pain, the tests found NO mets and no reason for concern. Turns out I had an infection running rampant. Peg, I leave for the UK on May 20th... but I should be here on the 19th if you want to have breakfast together. Leanne, have a wonderful vacation. Tina, you ROCK!!! Sandra, thank you for the report of your London weekend. have a great trip to Cyprus! Maxine, good to hear your news..... and that is all I can remember. Sorry, can't concentrate.  Take care all... *susan*
Posts.Title: Starting chemo Sept 05 Pegk susan_02143

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2008 11:24PM susan_02143 wrote: Hi All, So much has been happening lately, I am simply exhausted. Starting with the fun stuff... the wedding in Scotland was a blast. We took a sleeper train with a berth, and a working sink in the cabin! At the wedding there were lots of men in kilts, salmon prepared five ways, venison, cousins, friends, and lots of scottish dancing. How much fun. We were so far north, that the sun didn't go down until about 11:30 pm. We enjoyed traveling around the North of Scotland for several days. I managed to drive on the left with a stick shift without banging into anything! My father is not recovering from surgery well. He is in a nursing home now trying to get stronger. He has simply lost huge blocks of his memory. I am not sure where this will end up. I have just returned from spending two days with him, and though he is now able to walk, his mental state is so changed. My sister had her surgery, and is recovering really well. She can actually talk, and is fully understandable. She is relearning how to swallow, and I have spent a night with her, and made poached salmon and overcooked fresh pasta, and she was able to eat this. Yesterday was her set of checkups and she heard her pathology report. The lymph involvement was greater than expected, so they will add another chemo to her cocktail. For her, chemo is a radiology enabler. They say that the chemo will get the cancer dancing, and the radiation will zap it. She will start this next phase in two weeks. Since returning from Scotland, I have only spent two nights [not consecutive] at home. There is so much need right now. But I will stay put for a little bit since Lauren is coming home from her year abroad this weekend, and I will need to help her get re-settled in the parental house. Now, I am going to crawl into my bed and try to get rested again. *susan*
Posts.Title: Starting chemo Sept 05 Pegk susan_02143

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2008 09:55AM susan_02143 wrote: Sandra, just love the photos! I haven't put the Scotland pictures up on the web anywhere yet. Will let everyone know when I do. Life has been pretty overwhelming here since I returned. Lots of traveling between patients. Spent much of last week with my sister, taking her back and forth to the hospital. She had surgery for a PEG tube [oh yuck], didn't do well with the pre-surgery drugs and then a week later developed a terrible infection. Unfortunately, my sister lives one hour from my house. So each time, I drive an hour to her house, an hour back to the hospital [which is 3 miles from my house], back out to her house, and then back to mine. Four hours per trip! Today, she has her first radiation and Monday will begin the weekly chemo infusions. At this point, my Mom is taking over her care for the most part. I will be responsible for her for only about 3 days, and we actually don't expect her to need anything on those days. Phew! Good news is the kid is home and already working at her two jobs. She hasn't lived with us full time in a couple of years now, and we have done a good job of readjusting all of our expectations. Peg, have a great photo shoot. Work is drying up around here. I may have to consider doing some travel to get more. Just the nature of the economy right now. Best to all.....
Posts.Title: Starting chemo Sept 05 Pegk susan_02143

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2008 11:49PM susan_02143 wrote: It is now September 19, 2008. Over three years ago, I sat in that chair and watched red fluids being pushed into my veins. Each of us has an individual story of that first day. And each of us has found a path to "normal." Sandra has new breasts. Mine are getting moisturizer since infections are hanging out in my dry nipple. Leanne is busy being a almost-single mom, while Peg has a new kitchen. A kitchen that was delayed by her treatment. Calico is spending time with her mother, and worrying about her daughter. Tina has become an advocate for other woman, while enjoying her new husband and worrying about her kids. It has been a long time since anyone posted on this thread. Maybe we are done? Maybe we are ready to move on? Maybe. You all know how to find me. Be well. It has been a blessing to know each and every one of you.

Posts.Title: Starting chemo Sept 05 Pegk susan_02143

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2008 08:27PM susan_02143 wrote: So, I was eating lunch the other day. Before eating my first bite, I pulled out my handy-dandy pill dispenser and opened the appropriate cell. And then it hit me, it was December 15th. TWO YEARS until I am done with Aromasin!!!!! Odd how the side effects are getting less and less, and then SLAM, one day they are all back. Then the next day, I am fine. My father has had some setbacks ending up in the hospital for a few days. His short term memory almost doesn't exist.  My sister seems to be getting stronger and better with each passing day. My uncle gets worse, and my aunt gets better. This is like General Hospital, but we are a real family. We all head north on Wednesday. Once again we will decorate the tree on Christmas Eve with our Jewish friends joining in. I make gravalax, smoked fish, and serve with red onion, capers, bagels and some cream cheese. This year I may add some spanikopita and some soup. Perhaps a few special cookies, some mulled cider and a pie. The kid is a finalist for Teach for America, and she wants it so badly. She has been offered to TA positions for Spring term..... yea... I am proud. Be well all of my friends... *susan*
Posts.Title: Starting chemo Sept 05 Pegk susan_02143

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2009 11:48PM susan_02143 wrote: Gentle Bump! My kid got a job that she wants!!! Whoohoooo! We have had so much rain, a three-day nor'easter.... all of us feel waterlogged. Have decided to go to a yearly conference in August and extend for a few days to do a small vacation. My husband's first time in SF. We are looking forward to having some time together. All the news from here. Gosh, my life is boring.

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2009 10:36PM susan_02143 wrote: So, yesterday was the day. Scans were on Tuesday and the doctors on Thursday. Can I say, I have spent way too much time at this damn hospital! Okay. So the scans were not fun. Barium for breakfast is just disgusting. Then the contrast burst all over me and the floor. Totally ridiculous. Anyhow, saw the oncologist first on Thursday. Blood markers are still up, but down from last time. Scans are clean. We agreed that I would not have any more scans. I will not see him again for six months. And I was off to my mammo. The technician was so precise. She took so much time pushing and pulling. My poor surgical breast was truly put through the wringer, but she got the shots that she needed. I was off to see the surgeon. Well, her PA since I am not interesting anymore. And she made me wait for 40 minutes. By the time we went into the exam room I had reached the end of my patience rope. I turned down an MRI. At the end of the day, I just wanted to sit in a chair and cry. I have no idea why. Husband truly doesn't get it. This was all good news after all, but somehow it just drained me. I am just tired of looking for something to go wrong. I am willing to do blood tests, but I am refusing everything else. So, good news. I am having all the wrong responses, but am grateful and am backing out the system slowly! Nicole, sending all my thoughts..... *susan*

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2007 10:30PM susan_02143 wrote: I don't know where else to go tonight. Julie and I performed together over the years. We were never particularly close. Her lover was a married man, and when he died, he left her quite a bit of money. I couldn't get past the fact that she was willing to be that 'other' woman. And then our lives intersected again. We were dx'ed with breast cancer at the same time; both stage IIb. Julie decided that chemo was poison, and chose an 'alternative' path. Obviously, I chose the western medicine route. We simply couldn't connect after that. She died yesterday a year after hitting stage 4, still traveling around the world trying every cure. I am angry. I am angry that she didn't give herself the best shot possible, and I am angry that each of us has been changed forever by this disease. Peg.... walk away. Thank you for taking us with you. Love,  *susan*

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2007 11:21PM - edited Nov 5, 2007 11:21PM by susan_02143 Leanne, A part of me thinks that your doctors need to PROVE that they are correct. But, it sounds like it is getting in the way, so maybe you can find someone to talk to. To this day, I wish I had talked with someone after my brother died. My anger management is NOT the recommended way! I hope that you can find some peace. You deserve it. *susan*  oh! p.s. love hearing from you, even when it isn't pretty.

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2007 10:38PM susan_02143 wrote: * gentle bump * My daughter arrives from London on Tuesday, and I just can't wait to see her again. Miraculously, she feels the same way. To date, I haven't bought even one gift for Christmas. The idea of being jostled by crowds just horrifies me! It isn't that I don't love watching people open gifts that I have selected, I just can't bring myself to go shopping. Oh well..... it could be worse, right? A quick recap of me... my bone pain has almost disappeared. I have given up on the fosamax. It made me very sick. Once I stopped, the bone pain disappeared.... odd co-incidence, eh? I no longer need naps, and I am able to concentrate for at least 10 hours a day. This is good stuff. I have reasons to celebrate!  I hope that all of you are enjoying this season in whatever way you celebrate. *susan* p.s. 3 years to the day more on aromasin!

Posts.Content: May 3, 2010 02:53PM - edited May 3, 2010 03:34PM by susan_02143 I am officially Stage IV. Minimal for now, but I am entering this small club, reluctantly. I currently have mets in my lymph nodes and chest cavity. Waiting to schedule an appointment with my Onc to discuss the treatment options. I knew this was coming, and for the moment, feel totally deadened with a touch of sadness thrown in. At least I know that I did everything that the medical community can throw at breast cancer. This isn't a result of anything but bad luck. Please note: I am not telling anyone about this. My diagnosis gives me years of life and I can not afford to have my professional career railroaded again. So, I will not be posting about this on Facebook. Please respect my need for secrecy. All the best to my September Sisters....  *susan*

Posts.Title: Starting chemo Sept 05 Pegk susan_02143

Posts.Content: May 25, 2010 09:58AM susan_02143 wrote: It is really weird how little this progression has changed anything. It has changed me; it has changed my outlook, but I am not suddenly less-well and life just continues. I had a few faslodex side effects, maybe. I can't tell if this new amount of fatigue is my body's way of dealing with the stress and sadness, or the faslodex.  Telling my daughter was hard. She understood in waves what I was saying. As I finished she said "So this will never go away?" and just sobbed. But, I have decided that I am not telling my Mother, sisters, and family beyond husband and daughter until I am on a treatment plan that forces me to. It hasn't been easy to omit such a large piece of news from my conversations with them. I still think that this is the best plan for now. The gallbladder procedure was totally bogus. Wrong procedure for what ails me! By the time this became clear, the IV was in my veins and the drugs were flowing. Clearly, I will need to make sure that this never happens again. I will need to see a surgeon now, but I am not rushing. Next faslodex shot is next week. Will get my blood markers done then too, but it will be too early to tell if this new drug in the cocktail is having any effect. Today, I am 'running away from home'... going to visit a good friend who has moved to the Cape. A few days by the ocean before the season hits with someone that I love to laugh with. Really looking forward to this small break. *susan*

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2011 11:14AM susan_02143 wrote: Sandra, The NED thing means No Evidence of Disease, which means they can't find any mets in my system. The unsaid is that, there are nasty little mutant cells still there, and eventually they will figure out how to circumvent the drugs. But until then, I am in fact, considered to be, cancer free. Had another PET scan on December 23rd, and once again, "no signifigant findings." Those are really good words. My doctor actually called me that night to let me know the results! She didn't want me to worry over the Christmas weekend. I think she is a keeper. The way I am going, I am almost ready to hope that I will be one the long-termers. Just don't want to jinx my great luck.  :-)  Merry Christmas to all.... and a great 2012. The rest of you are moving on, and that is the way it should be. *susan*

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2013 10:30PM susan_02143 wrote: I too have chosen not to tell much of anyone. Why would I? At the moment I am NED and have no interest in others creating a death watch. Nor do I want to give anyone a reason to not hire me [I am self-employed.] To be honest, I can't think of one reason to tell people at all. I gave my daughter permission to tell very close friends so that she would have a support system. I did the same with my husband, and only in the past few months has he chosen to do so. My daughter was 18 when I was first dx'ed, and 23 when I progressed. My mother was told that if she told a single soul without my permission, I would no longer communicate with her. [She needs bounderies!] Can you give your son permission to create a group for himself? Random people in the grocery store don't really matter, do they? *susan*

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2010 01:11AM susan_02143 wrote: "don't go on the internets" Mostly, that is a correct statement. There are wildly outdated statistics, stories about side effects that seem too bad to be true, and medical sharmans. But this site is on a side street of the internet where compassion, honesty, and true caring can thrive. I too am on hormonals only, but my Stage IV dx came 5 years after the initial dx when I had the chemo, rads, and surgery. I am four months into this new progression and really hope that this pill plus a shot of Faslodex monthly is working. As far as treatments go, this is pretty easy. I am hoping for years if I can get them. So sorry you are here, but this is a wonderful group. And you are welcomed with open arms. *susan*
Posts.Title: Newly diagonised and scared kccatz chrissyb

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2018 08:59AM susan_02143 wrote: Hi Pam, You wrote "Taxol has all those premeds and a longer infusion." I was able to eliminate all the pre-meds within the first two cycles, so they might not be required. Of course, you don't know if you can eliminate them until you are actually getting the drug! Though not standard protocol, once we saw that the Taxol was working for me, we changed my infusion schedule to 3 on-2 off which I miss terribly! I am actually at the hospital more often with the Halavan. I totally get the "crushed to go to IV chemo." For me that was a line in the sand, and there was no going back. Almost two years later, and I still mourn the carefree days of old. :-) Susan
Posts.Title: Choices, Choices (Taxol, Navelbine, Halavan) pajim SandiBeach57

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2012 11:24AM susan_02143 wrote: Rohm, You know, generally when someone retires we would say "congratulations", but in this case that doesn't feel right. I am so sorry that you are unable to continue working at a job you like; and yet pleased that you are comfortable with this decision. The year after my initial diagnosis, when the economy tanked, I had very little work. During that year, I learned to make artisinal bread working my way through The Bread Baker's Assistant. I became a slave to the yeast and ferments. Is there something that intriques you that requires some precision and committment? For me, bread was just a means. And it didn't cost much to get started and gave me some structure. I suspect that you too will find something to fill your days. *susan*

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2008 08:32PM susan_02143 wrote: Thank you all. Today has been a whole new ballgame. The feeding tube was pulled, and she immediately had relief from the pain. Her pre-meds this wek included Aloxi and Emend. The nutricionist had her drink a high calorie Carnation during her infusion, and my sister immediately felt better! I was able to make her a smoothie with soy ice cream, the whey protein, almond milk, and a banana. Slipped right down! And now she is craving poached eggs. The hot and sour soup at Quindoa Garden is exactly what she is craving, so that is where I will go get her a quart. [Lumi, the Best Little Restaurant is excellent!] Love the idea of candied ginger, but since most of her tongue was removed and then rebuild, anything with sharp edges is contraindicated. However, ginger tea is working well for her. I will continue to update this thread regarding the nausea drugs and how they are working, for future cisplatin receivers.

Together we are trying to delay the use of the feeding tube as long as possible, but I fear that her medical team will require her to start using it this week. Today I am making her lots of high nutricion soups. She needs to consume 100 grams of protein a day and must stay hydrated. So far, smoothies and sweet potato soup are keeping her going. By adding protein whey to these we are getting close, but not close enough. Again, thank you for all of your suggestions. Now back to that hot kitchen to make something from roasted beets. *susan*

Posts.Content: May 6, 2014 02:39PM susan_02143 wrote: Roses, For me, it is a change of view. I live in Somerville, so if I have just a little bit of time, I head to the Charles River and just watch the boats. This works best on a sunny day [which have been in short supply lately.] I always stop and sit on a bench on the Cambridge side after treatment. Just makes me remember that I am a small piece of a much bigger world. The Mystic River works well too, and I plan to investigate the bike path over there soon. If I have a day or so, I head to the cape to visit friends, or north to the mountains. I can't climb those mountains anymore, but that doesn't matter. They give me a sense of well-being. Heck a trip to Revere Beach, with a stop at Kelly's or one of the Cambodian/Laoitian spots is fun. Or, I buy something a little special to make for dinner, even if it is just a nice bit of cheese. When it is warmer, a break, sitting in the garden with a cup of coffee reminds me that I am a really lucky person. For me, routine has always been a downer. A routine that is "being sick" is even worse. So, I do whatever I can to engage myself with things that are bigger than myself. *susan*

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2013 10:29AM susan_02143 wrote: Sundance, Are you just 6 weeks from diagnosis of mets? Or just six weeks since a change of therapy to Tamoxifen? If you the former, wow, give yourself some time. The first 6 months are just plain wretched! Thrown into menopause, forced to stare at your own mortality, grieving for a life changed forever, so very much. Talk with your doctor of course, but your current swings don't seem unjustifiable. If the latter, then it would seem that your new therapy is throwing your hormones and body for a loop, which of course it the whole point of estrogen therapy! Again, talk with your doctor. Be kind to yourself. Allow yourself to be as patient with you as you would be to a good friend. Breast cancer treatment is not for the weak after all. *susan*

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2011 11:43AM susan_02143 wrote: I am now 6 years, 1 month and 3 days out from my last chemo cycle, and I finally have most of my cognitive abilities back. But not all of them. Still have trouble learning new bodies of knowledge, but am easily able to retain new skills that are related to what I already know. All those studies that you have read about how to study and retain new information become even more important for those of us who have changed our body chemistry through the use of both chemo and hormonals. Study, then sleep. Try to be well-enough rested that your brain can focus. And retrain yourself to focus for longer periods of time. As Blue says, cancer takes more than our breasts. All the best, *susan*

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2011 02:31AM - edited Dec 14, 2011 02:32AM by susan_02143 bruburn, First off, I am sorry that life is so bleak right now.  I admit it. I bury things, a lot. But when it all becomes too overwhelming I need to change my environment in some way. If I have any energy, I go to the ocean and walk along the beach; or go to the North End of Boston and walk the streets listening to people speaking Italian. Or I might go to an ethnic market, buy anything that looks interesting and try to figure out how to make a tasty meal from ingredients whose names I can't pronounce. And then, when nothing else works, I call my friend Lucy on the Cape and tell her I need to run away from home. Being away from the phone, long walks along the beach with the Frisbee dog, and a place that is comfortable to put up my feet always seems to brighten my outlook. Best I can do... *susan*

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2012 02:22PM susan_02143 wrote: I am SO with you on this one. It was so bad, I switched my primary. I was sick and tired of being told that my <insert issue here> was because I had cancer. Well, this filter almost killed me! I was in pain and the stupid man kept saying it was a chemo side-effect FOUR years after my last infusion. The pain was actually, a gallbladder not functioning. The last time I needed antibiotics, I got the same song and dance. Cancer blah blah. I turned it around and said "Well, if I only have 5 years left, I won't have time to build up a resistance." The doctor's face was priceless, but the point was made that this was just stupid. Why should I, cancer or not, have a raging infection with no medication? You have hit one of my sore spots. *susan*
Posts.Title: Slight Rant--or Just Crabby? Cafelovr Rosevalley

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2012 08:57AM susan_02143 wrote: Jane, One of the difficulties we all have is getting doctors to NOT look through the cancer filter. I had some dreadful pain in my abdomin and upper right ribs for TWO years. Even my primary doctor was so blinded by the fact that I had had breast cancer, he didn't look at my entire body. Turns out that my gallbladder had stopped functioning. It took me two years to get a correct diagnosis, and my surgeon thinks I just missed dying from the obstructions. I would suggest that you see your primary and insist that all possible pain reasons be investigated. Sure. It could be cancer or drug side effect related, but maybe not. *susan*

Posts.Content: susan_02143 wrote: This afternoon I received a call from Nurse Lauren, my oncologist's PA. I am not waiting for scan results, so this call was pretty unexpected. In fact, I couldn't imagine why she would be calling. She doesn't do scheduling either.  After the normal pleasantries she informed me that Dr. Roger, my wonderful oncologist, has taken a personal leave of absence with no known return date. When I questioned her, the tone of her voice led me to believe that this might very well be permanent. My world has been turned upside down. Dr. Roger and I have been together for 6 years. He is an outside the box thinker, who feels comfortable with my questions and thoughts. He considers me part of the team. And we have a great time talking about where to get really delicious ethnic foods for under $10 per person. With my blood markers rising, this is when I need Dr. Roger! I can't believe that I have lost this person from my medical team, if only for a few months. I am going to have to teach a new doctor who I am, and figure out her priorities, and hope that I don't piss her off, plus trust someone new. Nurse Lauren remains as my PA, Nurse Linda continues as my oncology nurse, but I have been transfered to Dr. Christina. She is very young. Has the perfect resume. Dr. Christina wants scans. She isn't Dr. Roger. Blood work and Faslodex will remain the same for next week, but I won't meet my new doctor until the scan results are back. After the call was over, I burst into tears. I didn't really realize how I felt, don't cry easily so this clearly has me upset. I did my business conference call and did what anyone would do- took a nap. I am going to miss Dr. Roger tremendously. anotherplan.blogspot.com... and its back. May 3, 2010 mets found. Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2014 06:21AM susan_02143 wrote: Happy Birthday Chris! I felt the same as you the first year after progression and was devastated that no one planned anything for my day. I just assumed that they would "get" that any birthday was a time to celebrate not being dead. Nope. So since then, each of the subsequent three years, I plan the birthday that I want. I make reservations to one of those just-out-of-reach restaurants that I want to try. I invite the people I want to celebrate with, and celebrate my day. Posts.Content: susan_02143 wrote: On May 3, 2010 I was given the news that not only was my gallbladder impacted and about to explode, but there were mets in two locations. This was actually good news since the pain we were investigating could have been widespread bone mets. How will I celebrate? With some blood work and my 25th monthly Faslodex shots. My hope back then was to get at least 2 years from the Faslodex. Now I want more! Last month's blood work showed a 26.3% increase in my 25.29 blood markers. Until this month's numbers come back, there is that little nagging voice in the back of my head. Hard to have a real celebration as long as that little voice is yammering away. Without this forum I don't know that I could have made it through those first 6 months. I wish to thank all of you for helping me get myself of that ledge and back into a world where I can function, at least most of the time. Be well, *susan*  anotherplan.blogspot.com... and its back. Posts.Content: May 21, 2012 07:21AM susan_02143 wrote: Sue, These are all big questions indeed! I am not a big fan of financial planners, but a good one might make some sense right now. Our circumstances are different. I am almost 10 years older than you. I have a husband though I have been the primary wage earner for most of our lives together. My house is a reasonable neighborhood and might actually sell. 1. I am going to work as long as I possibly can. I don't have any disability options besides SSDI, and by definition, SSDI will be a lot less money than earned income. Plus I like to work. 2. Retirement funds will be essential after you stop working. Once you are declared disabled, those funds will be available to you as a monthly income with no penality. By not paying taxes on that money now, while your income is healthy, is actually a pretty big savings. We have to change our definition of retirement which takes a bit of head turning. I would continue to invest in a retirement fund as long as you are working, and don't need the cash for other uses. 3. I too bought a fixer house, and we have begun really fixing it up. Though my husband likes to pretend that he can make more money so that we can stay in this house, my practical side knows that the overhead will be too much when I am no longer a fully functional income generator. So, I am not planning to put the house on the market, but I want it to be ready to show when that becomes the only option. Your case sounds more complicated however since your capital has been lowered through home ownership. You will have to weigh the pros and cons of ownership, keeping both financial and emotional components in the mix. 4. I have begun researching less expensive areas of the country to move to when things here begin to decline. My criteria has been near a major medical center, not too cold in the winter or too hot in the summer, and near a "hub" airport. And relatively cheap to live. [There aren't many places that fit this criteria, I am sad to say.] Support systems and friends are all good, but in reality, we all rely on ourselves to get through this. 5. There are a few other things that I have done to prepare. Too specific for this post. I am planning for the worst while striving to be present and joyful in daily life. It took me a long time to get here though. It sounds like you are well on your way to getting there. All the best, *susan*

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2012 12:07PM susan_02143 wrote: exbrn, I know that some woman at my center are getting test [maybe not hte onco] that determines if the specific chemo will be effective for your specific tumor. I am at a teaching hospital that is generally on the front end of technologies, so maybe this isn't available anywhere. [I do realize that the onco test isn't for us, but heck its out there. Was worth a thought.] The percentage ER does matter. High ER% generally means that response to the treatment of hormones is faster, but not more effective. For me, it turns out that my ER expression is the "B" expression, so Faslodex works for me, while the Aromasin which I was on when I presented with mets and targets the "A" expression. Sadly, there is no test yet to determine which expression is the one that needs to be blocked. *susan*

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2012 11:18AM susan_02143 wrote: Fellow Grade 1 with mets person here. Has anyone considered the onco test on your biopsy tissue to determine if your tumor will respond well to chemo? I did have chemo back in 2005 when I was first diagnosed [obviously THAT didn't work that well] but that was before this test existed. There have been some reports that Grade 1 tumors with low ER+ percentages respond better to hormone therapies than chemo. Just seems to me that it would be helpful to understand how _your_ tumor would respond to ACT so you have as much information as possible. Just a thought, *susan*

Posts.Content: susan_02143 wrote: My sister, a 17 year lymphoma survivor, is now being treated for oral cancer. She has had surgery and is now being treated with radiation and weekly cisplatin/erbitox. As of today, she has had 10 days of radiation and two of seven chemo infusions. Both weeks, she has had terrible nausea. Food smells make her gag. She has a metallic taste in her mouth and generally feels lousy. I made her a ton of homemade simple foods, and nothing appeals to her. Currently she has zofran during the infusion, and dissolving zofran tablets for managing the nausea at home. This isn't working well enough. What other options are there for helping her while on these chemos? All suggestions of food [I am willing to cook her anything] and/or meds that could help her would be most appreciated. Many thanks in advance,  *susan* p.s. I did post this in "Getting through Treatments" 20 hours ago, but no responses there. Maybe this forum would be a better place.   anotherplan.blogspot.com... and its back. May 3, 2010 mets found. Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2012 11:13AM susan_02143 wrote: You know, this discussion has been quite interesting. My new primary, nicknamed "sperm of the devil", is just like this young doctor in the interview. She is simply too young to have had any experience in real life at all and is so damn sure that she is a gift to humankind that she can't imagine anyone with a different life experience. Fundamentally, she has absolutely no empathy. But it is a slippery slope. My oncologist believes that at least half of her early stage ER+ patients are non-compliant with their hormonal drugs. So, when they present with mets, should she not treat them since they didn't comply? Many of us [with the exception of Ann] have gained weight on these hormonal drugs and/or steroids but we all know that increases our risk of mets. Do you not treat overweight people for mets since "they brought in on themselves" or "anyone can loose weight?" I believe we are heading into a time when medical care will be withheld from those that make choices that aren't in their best interest. Or were forced into unhealthy environments by their lack of resources. Or just make one stupid mistake. We already deny people without money health care. Not such a great leap to believe that other barometers will be used in the future. I think this is a very complicated subject with no "right" answer. People far smarter than I can't find the balance, but it is a discussion that is clearly happening. *susan*

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2012 01:03PM susan_02143 wrote: Another Grade 1 gal here. I think there are MANY reasons to start with the hormonals to be honest. Many of us have great success with them. Some research indicates that Grade 1 folks get more time with them. I am currently at almost 2 years living with NED from Faslodex. [Aromasin failed me first.] Chemo, though doable, is harsh. It weakens you and then you have to get back your strength while now taking the hormonals. There is no hiding that you have cancer. Your life has to be scaled back. It altered my body in ways that I am still aware of. Knowing what I know now, if I had been diagnosed Stage IV from the start, I would not have chosen the chemo first. Of course, that isn't how my life has played out and I don't have any regrets. Good luck making your decision. *susan*

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2014 09:03AM susan_02143 wrote: Barb, I have never measured, so can't give an exact amount. For me, a restaurant meal is enough salt since I rarely eat in restaurants and find the sodium levels very high. For my popcorn, I simply salt until I can really taste the salt, but not so much that it isn't enjoyable to eat. The day before a blood draw, I try to drink at least 2 litres of water after dinner, and then some more in the AM. The morning water is a goal, not a reality. My stomach finds water when it is empty nasty; in fact, it doesn't like early morning food either. Just coffee. I think this sort of thing is all about experimenting and finding what works for you. I ask my nurse each time how "puffy" my veins are, and of course, i can always tell if they aren't puffy enough for a painless draw. *susan*

The reason it is important for ME to know when my tumor began growing is so that my daughter's insurance will pay for mammograms long before she gets to 40. The rule of thumb is 10 years before your Mother's BC began. So my daughter and my first cousin were able to get their first mammo at the age of 25 covered by insurance, since I agreed to participate in this study. I can't change my past, but I can have a positive impact on my relatives' future. *susan*

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2011 04:05PM susan_02143 wrote: My crystal ball is in the shop right now, but I can speak to Faslodex. Of course, your markers could be your early alert system. Or they could just be high today. Faslodex is different than Femara. It prevents the receipt of the estrogen expression B, while Femara prevents the creation of estrogen expression A. Since I am on both aromasin and Faslodex, targetting both expressions, I can't tell you which of my side effects are a result of either drug singly or combination. However, overall, it is not a bad treatment at all. Though this repeats what is in the "sticky" Hormone thread , there are a few tricks to reducing the pain of the injection. You should absolutely NOT ALLOW them to do the injections until the syringe has reached room temperature. EVER. It generally takes about 30 minutes for the drug to warm up. you can speed that up by holding the syringe in your hand. Generally, the shot is given while one is standing. Each shot will be given in a cheek butt. While they do cheek left, position your body so that your weight is on the right leg. And then switch for the other shot. Lately, I have found that I do better when the shot is given in the upper portion of my ever-expanding butt. Work with your nurse to come up with the best spot for you, assuming you get the same nurse every month. We hope that you will have many months of NED to test different spots. And for comparison, my markers were 44 at dx. 118 when we found the mets, and now hang out around 77. Scans don't find anything. My strange way of dealing with this is I imagine that the 77 means that my body is actively fighting off the cancer... so I don't have active mets but they are trying to find a hospitible spot. [Yea, weird I know, but it helps me as I take these drugs.] Wow, this was wordy... I hope it is a bit of a help. *susan*

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2011 03:51AM susan_02143 wrote: Yes. It is all that and more isn't it? So a few thoughts, if I might. There are things that others can do for you to free up your time for the good stuff. [of course, you do have to decide what the good stuff is!] Grocery shopping is a huge time and energy sucker. Keep a list. Have a friend pick up your list when they are headed to the store, do your shopping, keeping a separate receipt and you pay them for the cost of the groceries. This is really common around here, and often there will be someone buying for up to 5 people. Yes it slows down the checkout line, but really, why would you care? This friend also needs to be non-judgmental. If you put chocolate chip, carmel swirl ice cream on the list, NO COMMENTS. Sometimes mets needs some ice cream. Apple picking... as an example. Is it picking the apples or the making of the pie that appeals to you most? Pick one, and find someone, even your husband perhaps, who can do the other part. Not enough energy to make the crust, add it to the aforementioned shopping list. Teaching the young one to read. Could you "supervise" one of the older kids taking this on? All of you snuggled in a chair or on the bed? It is hard not to beat ourselves up. We KNOW what we want to do on a daily basis. We just can't always DO it. I am finding that if I look at my life in weekly batches instead of daily ones, I can find more room to be gentle with myself and my expectations. Does this make any sense? *susan*

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2008 11:26PM - edited Apr 24, 2008 11:27PM by susan_02143 Lucky, A long time ago, my aunt (the favorite one) became unable to walk due to her breast cancer mets. My father renovated a sun porch for her, creating a fully assessibe bath and bedroom. All the doorways on the first floor were already wide enough for the chair. Dad built the bathroom so that the chair could roll into the shower and over the toilet. She was able to take care of her own personal needs. Things we found useful: 1. long tongie things so she could pull items off of shelves, or from kitchen cabinets  2. a plastic seat shifter.... this was a plastic seat that one could use to get into the car. you faced it towards the car door, sit on it, and then it could swivle to look forward 3. we ramped the house. neighbors complained and we could have cared less 4. back in those days it was novel, but we had a remote control for the TV 5. a desk on wheels that had an adjustable height. She used it to hold books, etc, nowadays it would be good for a laptop 4. at the bottom of the ramp, we created a shaded patio so she could easily go outside in good weather. The world is an easier place now for people in wheelchairs. This was back in the early 1980's. She had to be carried into Symphony Hall to listen to a concert. Even the hospital wasn't fully wheelchair friendly. As I type this, it amazes me that my father did all of this work for his sister in law. Maybe your house can accommodate some of these fittings to make your life easier. All the best, *susan* p.s. if you want to send that same Dad some positive vibes, he is currently in ICU unable to breath on his own following an open heart surgery, please feel free.

Posts.Content: susan_02143 wrote: Our dear sister Kirsti has lost her battle with breast cancer. Some of you may remember her few posts from over a year ago. In March her doctors ceased treatment, and after a very painful 2 months, she died on May 2, 2007. I became very concerned when she stopped emailing, and called her phone numbers during my travels to France this month. They had been disconnected. A little more research and I found her diary in her native tongue. A good friend had posted for her during the final weeks. Her final weeks were filled with pain and hope. She and her husband Nils finally actually talked about this damn beast, and she died feeling loved by those she loved the most... her husband, her close friends and her family. Loosing Roza and Kirsti in such a short time has me reeling emotionally. Well my emotional state isn't important.... but the gifts that Roza and Kirsti brought to each of us are. Posts.Content: susan_02143 wrote: For me, the start of Fall has always been the day after Labor Day. In New England, this is the traditional start of school, and since we have so many academic institutions in the Boston area, it is the default start of a new year. I was originally diagnosed with breast cancer the week before my daughter's high school graduation. Of course, there was no reason to tell her or my parents until that celebratory weekend was over. I delayed the start of chemo until after I took my daughter to college. To me there was nothing more important than making sure that she could do well in school. It is now six and a half years later and today, I am watching this same young woman start graduate school. She is now 25, but the same girl that I sent to kindergarden is before me. She is excited. She is nervous. She wants the right folders that only she can pick out. She is one of the many reasons I try to stay grounded and focused. My daughter has picked a career that will never compensate her well, but will make the world a better place for many. I am proud of her. I am proud of my husband and me for raising a woman who views the world with empathy and care. Please share your first day of school stories.... there must be others that are watching their children start their year.  anotherplan.blogspot.com... and its back. May 3, 2010 mets found. Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2012 03:00AM susan_02143 wrote: Iwill, I am going to contradict you just a bit. Aggressively doesn't automatically mean chemo. I got to NED with a combination of Faslodex and Aromasin. During my early stage dx, I used up half my lifetime A/C's. My doctors consider their decisions to be based on an intimate understanding of MY tumors and they consider the treatments that I am receiving to be aggressively going after my cancer. Posts.Content: May 18, 2010 10:59AM susan_02143 wrote: My blood work does include the TM's, but it also includes a ton of other stuff. Your normal blood marker number will be different than mine, or anyone elses. Following surgery I was a 44 and presumably there was no cancer in my body at that moment in time. After chemo it fell to 35 and sat there for 3 years. Bouncing a little, but always between the 35 and 44. Technically, this is high, but it appears that this number is my bottom. Since then, in the past 18 months my markers have gone up first steadily and then quickly. I am now above 150. At 66, they did a series of scans and found no cancer activity. 6 months later I was at 117, and the scans started again. This time the mets showed up. The oncologist concludes that chances are the mets were there at 66, but not yet visible. I consider myself lucky that the blood markers are a good indicator of activity. So, I believe that the usefulness of blood markers has to do with direction not actual numbers, but only if your markers actually respond to cancer. Hope this helps, *susan*

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2010 10:27AM susan_02143 wrote: Diane, Instead of being switched to the Faslodex when I progressed to Stage IV, my onc added Faslodex to my existing aromasin protocol. I have now had 4 injections, so three complete monthly cycles. The Faslodex appears to be working with my blood markers down almost 20%. My first three months of Faslodex I had increased fatigue and felt vaguely sick, like a cold, for about 10 days. I was napping at 11am for a few quick minutes and then again in the late afternoon. This month I don't feel these effects, but maybe I am just so elated to see those markers going down, I am not noticing! My injection sites do hurt. Quite a bit. More than most I think. But I haven't felt any strange sensations that aren't butt-related. I am not doing a tremendous amount of exercise, just some walking and the only thing I feel from that is the bone pain from the aromasin. Hope that this is a bit helpful. All the best, *susan*

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2011 04:18PM susan_02143 wrote: Laurie, Your tumor markers do sound like they are accurate for you, however, they only measure cancer activity at the moment that the blood is taken. It is not a window into future performance [as they say in the financial industry.] I am currently NED, and my blood markers are sitting at 80. My "low" was 44. When my mets were active, my numbers had gone from that 44 to 117. Though I am delighted to be NED right now, I know that my cancer will figure out my current treatment at some point, and start to flourish again. [That is Lena's term, and it is a good one.] I am trying to enjoy this time while my treatments are still fairly easy, and not look ahead too much. Every day that my mets aren't growing is a day that my mets aren't growing. If that makes sense. I think people like good news and celebrate any successes that are achieved. Congratulations on being NED! *susan*

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2012 12:34AM susan_02143 wrote: Laurie, You would think choosing a potential guardian would be easy. A sister, your mother... well not in my case. [shudder] When our daughter was young, picking someone to care for her in the event of was almost impossible. It took us some time, but we were able to get another couple to agree to be the designated guardian. Of course, I have no idea if my family [or my husband's] would have fought that choice in court. Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2017 10:55PM - edited Apr 10, 2017 12:18AM by susan_02143 I don't quite understand some of the responses to your question. The ACA has not been changed with this new administration. Nothing has been passed in Congress to change the ACA. Having a pre-existing conditions does not mean that you can not get insurance, nor do you pay more than your peers. Depending on which state you plan to return to, your choices for health insurance plans [self-pay] can be very good or wretched. Choose your state wisely. Even the most draconian proposals for changing the ACA, which do not have enough votes to pass, will continue to allow people with illness to continue to buy insurance if they have been covered for the previous year. BUT, those changes have NOT been voted into law. Some states have accepted extra money so that if you return without a job, you might very well be heavily subsidized. I have no employer. I have never had an employer. I have always had self-pay and I have insurance that has covered absolutely all of my treatments. That said, insurance is expensive and will probably become more so now that the IRS has been told to NOT apply the penalties for not having insurance. *susan*  EDITED to ADD: Every single one of us is covered under the ACA, regardless of who pays for the coverage. The ACA dictates who and what must be covered as a minimum.

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2010 12:35PM susan_02143 wrote: I did the test at the urging of my entire medical team. Numerous cancers, maternal aunt who was diagnosed at 36 with breast cancer and died at 46, in addition to being the only woman beside this aunt who hadn't had ovaries removed due to unusual growths. The genetics counselor created a family tree and made notations on each stick figure about their health history. It was actually a fair amount of work to assemble the required information. After the meeting the genetics counselor, who is also an oncologist, calculated that I had an 18% chance of a BRCA anomoly, and so the test was approved. First report indicated that I was not BRCA positive but that there was a gene expression which was "off" but with unknown consequences. Two years later I received a second report expressing that my "off" was now understood, and was unrelated to breast cancer or cancer of any kind. Without a family history of "female" cancers, generally this test is not performed, I assume based on both the cost and the fact that only 5% of breast cancer is attributable to BRCA. My assumption is that there will be other indicators within our DNA, but the research is still in its infancy. Hope this helps, *susan*

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2010 08:44AM susan_02143 wrote: I am SO NOT a fashion maven. When I was bald, I put very little effort into not looking bald. I had a black skull cap to keep my head warm, and otherwise I was bare. But, I did wear more dramatic ear-rings which looked good without hair around them. I was offered a class called Look Good, Feel Better. They are held all over the country. My understanding is that these classes help you learn how to use makeup and various head scarf tying techniques, etc. Around here, the women who participate go home with some free samples. Might be worth finding a similar class in your neck of the woods. http://lookgoodfeelbetter.org/ I don't think you need to be too matchy-matchy. I mean, you didn't change the color of your hair every day to match your outfit. Find two or three colors that you like and compliment your skin tone, and go with it. *susan*

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2011 06:47AM susan_02143 wrote: radiant, You might want to investigate the world of Asian soups. Assuming that you eat meat, you start with a basic chicken stock cooked with scallions and ginger, and from there, you can do so many things. A basic noodle soup with some cabbage, all the way to a fancy soup with grilled pork, mushrooms, green onions and cabbage. Take some of the same stock and simmer with a pork bone, and you intensify the flavor. One of my most favorite soups is a Vietnamese Pho, a rich beef broth with sliced beef, Thai basil, sprouts, and some other condiments that you can choose to add. Making Pho does take some time and the cost of beef bones has skyrocketed lately so this has become a special occasion soup.  And then of course there is Miso soup, Japan's great gift to the world. This is the fastest and easiest soup in the world to make, if you can find the ingredients nearby.  Of course these soups don't cure cancer, but I find that I feel stronger and sated when I make these soups part of my regular diet. I will be happy to post my chicken stock process for you later, if that interests you. Hope this helps, *soup susan*

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2011 06:04PM susan_02143 wrote: Molly, Shocking isn't it? No chemo... we want those big guns, but your sister's doctor is following a pretty standard protocol. Use the gentler treatments as long as possible, before moving to the chemo track. If your sister is lucky, she will be able to use different hormonal treatments for years. These treatments actually do work for some! I am stable on a combination of two hormonal treatments. In my dream world, I hope to get five years from this combination. As chainsawz stated, there is no cure for what ails us. For me, this isn't a fight but a complex chess match where I hope that my doctors and I can out play the cancer for as long as possible. John Hopkins is considered to be one of the best hospitals in the country. Nothing in your post indicates that you must have a second opinion, but of course that is your sister's decision. Sorry that she has moved into our little world. I would recommend that she consider joining this group. We have our ups and downs, yes, we loose some beautiful women, but this board allows all of us to have a community that can give hope for a meaningful life. *susan*

Posts.Content: susan_02143 wrote: Amontro, I hope that you are willing to do our Five Questions. If not, don't respond or send me a PM, and I will pick someone else and post new questions on Thursday. If you do choose to play along, please post YOUR new questions for one of our fellow forum members within the next three days. 1. You are still working at the age of 70 which is impressive for anyone, much less someone well past the "traditional" retirement age. What kind of work do you do? Do you do it because you love it, or because you need the income, or both? If you could retire tomorrow, would you? 2. Over the past year, you have had some physical challenges and have needed pain meds and hydration. There may have been more, but my memory fails me. Are you still managing the side effects of your treatment or have you found the right mix of medication to keep them under control? 3. Who is your support system? Do you have a significant other, children, extended family, and/or chosen family? Who among them makes you smile? 4. And speaking of smiling, what gives you joy in your daily life? What do you look forward to? 5. Do you live in the United States? If not, where are you located? If you are, what region? Can you help build a picture of what it is like where you live? I love to imagine the countryside and architecture of people's home areas. Have you always lived there or did you choose this location for some particular reason. 6. As always, the bonus question is-- what was I not clever enough to ask that you would like us to know? Can't wait to hear your responses! *susan* anotherplan.blogspot.com... and its back. Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2012 07:46PM susan_02143 wrote: hi Sue, I will slide past the question about drugs since I have no experience with any of that class of drugs, and instead move right into your business partnership. At the risk of sounding way too practical and not warm and fuzzy enough, do you have a legal agreement with this partner above and beyond your co-mortgage? Are you eq ually responsible for this mortage [50/50] or is there a different distribution? I am going to assume you are not able to buy this person out, so have you considered hiring a lawyer to sue her for breach of contract? Is your area in a deep real estate slump or is there any chance of selling the property for the value of the mortgage? I can't imagine going through this. Whatever feelings you once had for this person will need to be put to the side and you have to fight for your family's best interests. This could include sueing so you can garnish her wages [after all she is ascending!] Sue above mentioned getting other investors, who perhaps could buy in at less than full value [i.e. .20 on the dollar.] This is the perfect place to post this I think. You are part of our community and we do try to support each other through all the nastiness that our diagnosis bring to us. *susan*

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2011 11:00AM susan_02143 wrote: jamaker, Ah. Excersise of any kind is good during radiation [and would have been good during chemo if you had it.] I walked. My supermarket was exactly 1/2 mile of walking if I did every single aisle [cutting out the cleaning supply one. yuck did that one smell.] And I would walk the aisles twice. I chose a supermarket since the aisles were wide, the floor was even, and it was wintertime here so ice, snow and cold were an impediment to moving around. If you can do this daily, you will retain your energy levels for longer. It isn't perfect of course. I still napped. But I am convinced that it made a difference for me. Good luck! *susan*

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2015 08:31AM - edited Mar 11, 2015 08:33AM by susan_02143 Deak, I had my thyroid removed two years ago, reluctantly. As you can imagine, I had many of your same fears about the scar. Heck when the doctor marked my neck in the pre-OP I actually asked him if it was legal to cut someone like that! Post-surgery I looked like an extra from Sweeney Todd. But, my surgeon was an artist and did the incision in one of my ever-increasing neck creases. Within 6 months, it had faded to a slightly different color. At two years out, it is almost impossible to find. I wore a scarf for the first year [though I wear them pretty frequently anyhow] and the only person who mentioned the scar had a matching one to show me. In my case, they reinserted the parathyroids since my problem was Graves disease [hypo.] If you want the name of my surgeon here in Boston, send me a PM. *susan* p.s. And the ONLY area of the body that this surgeon touches is the neck region; a true specialist. Hundreds a year.... at a major hospital.

Posts.Content: May 27, 2014 10:32PM susan_02143 wrote: I am in the minority. I don't take anything [well besides my bp meds, thyroid replacements and that monthly Faslodex shot.] I don't seem to have anxiety or depression about this blasted disease. I would not hesitate to ask for medication help if I needed it and I am pretty sure my onc is always evaluating my mental condition.  I have had bouts of tremendous sadness when we have lost our dear sisters, but for me, that isn't a drug-need moment. It is a moment to need the mountains, woods, or an ocean. It is a time to celebrate the thing that made me love them. And it is a time to mourn a life wasted. My only reason for posting is so that lurkers know that some people might be like them and not need or want medication, just yet. *susan*

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2013 09:50PM susan_02143 wrote: The first week of October will find the leaves changing across the southern tier of Vermont and New Hampshire. Vermont does have the most beautiful colors if that is what you are seeking. I think using Manchester, VT or Bennington, VT as "home base" puts you into some of the most beautiful countryside. From there you can visit quite a few historic sites [if that is what you are interested in] associated with the Revolutionary War. If Maine is your real love, I would probably consider using Portsmouth, NH as a base. This is wonderful town with lots of places in town where you can walk to find a restaurant, etc. A bit farther north is Portland, ME which is also a funky little city with lots of places to walk, etc. Either of these spots would be great places to use as exploring bases. Post about what interests you.... hiking, history, old art, artists, leaves, sport, etc and we could help you a lot more. Our little part of the world has so much to offer, but gives us a few clues. *susan*

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2013 09:43PM susan_02143 wrote: Lisa, You will never get a report that says Stage IV, since that isn't the diagnosis. The diagnosis will  include the words "metastasized breast cancer." My reports all have my original diagnosis, with the addition of these three words. I will never be Stage IV by Boston medical standards. I will always be Stage IIb, with mets. Your original staging doesn't get modified, just appended. As to a cancer insurance plan, I don't think it will pay out until your reports remove the word "suspicious." But I could be wrong about that one. It might be sufficient if your onc begins to treat you are someone with mets, and is willing to say so on an insurance report. My mets were not biopsied. The risk of biopsy was not worth the benefits. *susan*

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2012 09:26AM - edited Nov 14, 2012 09:26AM by susan_02143 I think that the term "aggressive" is problematic. What does that really mean? Does it mean a chemo that makes you sicker than another or what? I see that you are on Xeloda. In my world that seems aggressive. I, for one, am thrilled that my simple Faslodex treatments are working. I don't really want anything more powerful than what is needed. I am not going for a cure; I don't believe that there is one. I do want a life that is as normal as possible for as long as possible. When I was first diagnosed, I was hit with the big guns and clearly they didn't work! To me it is a miracle that one shot a month can be so powerful. It seems that you should have a chat, a serious chat, with your oncologist if you don't think s/he is doing enough. Complicated stuff, eh? *susan*

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2012 01:05PM susan_02143 wrote: I met with a counselor to determine if the test was warranted. We did a full family tree and it was determined that I had a 13% chance of being positive. Since I have a daughter, and several first cousins of child bearing age, I did have the test done. There was a mutation of unknown importance and negative for the two BRAC's. Several years later I received a letter indicating that "unknown" was now known and was not an indicator for breast cancer. Meeting with the genetics counselor doesn't obligate you to the test. It does give you a sense of what your chances of being positive might be. With no cancer in your generation or the generation above you, it seems that this test might be overkill. *susan*

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2013 07:39PM susan_02143 wrote: Pat Frappier's services were at the funeral home, after the visiting time. My brother's service was in a non-denominational country church, the same one that almost all the rest of my family has used. I have been to services at an art center, armoury [decommissioned], and in a living room. You really can't rent a church, and most churches would expect that you would have been a member [or a survivor that is sponsoring the service was a member.] If you think of all the places that people have weddings, it might give you some other ideas: boat houses, historic homes, on a beach, in a coutry club or housing association club house, or art museum. Heck, I think you could rent a private room at a restaurant, serve a meal, and have people speak or just tell stories. I am still working on this one. I want it to be a place that reflects who I was in life, and allows people to speak with love and joy with each other. To be honest, if we can still afford this house, I figure it should happen right here. But if we have had to move for mobility reasons, [or financial], I will need to find another spot. For me, it will also need to be a place that makes my husband and kid comfortable. After all, they are the ones who actually have to be there. *susan*
