Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2014 04:57PM susan_02143 wrote: I am racking my brain to think of factories on Cape Cod. I believe that there were five factories on the inner Cape that made glass in the late 1800's. There is one factory now that makes potato chips. I would also contest the idea that Cape Cod is not rural. The real factories in New England were all along rivers... Manchester NH, Merrimack NH, Maynard, MA, Haverill, MA, along with many, many others. These factories all made textiles, including leather [which produces very toxic by-products.] These factories were all closed with very few exceptions by 1936. The depression was hard on them, but the kicker was the huge flood of 1934 [I think.] It wiped out all the machinery on the first and second floors of the riverfront factories. That combined with the rise of unions was the death knell for this industry in the Northeast. At that point they moved to Georgia [towels], Burlington, NC, etc. So why doesn't the Southeast have the same BC rates along those river towns? I am convinced that environmental issues are a trigger for this disease. In fact, I suspect it is the trigger for many diseases. I just can't square this author's statement with my intimate knowledge of Cape Cod and Long Island [which was mostly agricultural.] I think that any compound that is created by industry should be tested extensively. This is not a view shared by industry, of course. *susan*

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2011 10:19AM - edited Jan 30, 2011 10:20AM by susan_02143 I think that you can drive yourself crazy trying to determine why any of us got cancer. There are women on this site who are vegans, fat, skinny, fancy houses with no toxins, power lines, some sex, lots of sex, children, no children, breast fed or didn't (and you can add a ton more attributes.) My suspicion is that the elements that cause cancer are so complicated that the medical profession has only begun to scratch the surface. Perhaps she can join this site and see how many of us are living full lives even in the face of the Beast. *susan*

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2013 07:14AM susan_02143 wrote: I believe that Divine has touched on an important aspect. How "expected" the college track is/was for high school students has a lot to do with where you were raised. My high school class of 492 kids assumed that most kids would be college bound. Of those that graduated that year, 91% went to college. Of those 91%, 14% went to an Ivy League. My parents now live in a different area where the high school classes are about 200, and of the graduates this year, only 21% are going to a 4-year college, and only 1 of those is headed to an Ivy. Most go to a state college. My parents place is in the land of paper mills and timbering. The culture of not going to college continues into this generation even though those mills are closing one by one. Right now, there are only two mills running; one with only 220 employees and the other with just at 500. Once upon a time, there were thousands and thousands of jobs at those mills. I am a great believer in education. In the perfect world every single kid would have a love of learning new things be it how to fix a car, read the stars or a book, count insects. What stimulates you isn't as in important as that something does! *susan*

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2012 08:44AM susan_02143 wrote: My understanding is that there are two ways to transfer to a new medical facility. The first is the old-fashioned way. You ask you current onc if they know anyone at the new facility, or at least if they will make a call to "transfer" you. Doctor to Doctor is always going to be the most seamless transition. In LA, I assume you are considering UCLA or Cedar-Sinai. They both have a breast care center with a coordinator. If you need to transfer yourself, I would start by calling the coordinator, and have them help you transfer your records, etc. This is not like being accepted to college. They are hospitals. They need patients. You are a patient, and assuming you have some kind of health insurance, I can't imagine that being accepted will be difficult. I would start this process at least 6 weeks before you are actually planning to move, and have an appointment on the books before you leave WI. The new facility may insist on new scans and bloodwork, or maybe not. The more information they have in advance, the easier it should be. However, I would have a second copy of all your records with you in case they are misplaced or sent too late. Hope this helps. *susan*

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2012 05:23PM susan_02143 wrote: My goodness Sue, This is just too much. I am going to skip over the medical stuff and head right to the big elephant in the room. Money. You clearly don't have enough of it. There is nothing more stressful than not having enough money to cover the basics. I am not a big "new-agie" kind of gal. I don't believe stress caused my cancer, but I do think that it makes it harder to get stronger. You seem to live in what I consider to be "the middle of nowhere" so I don't know what resources you might have at your disposal. But, I think you need help. In Massachusetts utility companies are forbidden from turning off the power during the winter months. If your heat is gas, the same thing applies. There is no "basement" for those of us who heat with oil though. Maybe NY has the same type of regulations. Are there any emergency groups in your area? Perhaps you can get food from a food bank for a couple of months so that you can divert those funds to your furnace? There might be a county agency that has emergency funds for "disabled" people to get help with heating. Even the Red Cross might know where to get some assistance. We aren't that many paychecks away from needing assistance. It wasn't so long ago when we made choices between food and antibiotics, so I really undestand how hard this is to manage. You may not get a break, but you might be able to find one. All the best, *susan* - who if she had even an extra penny, would send some cash your way.

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 03:12PM susan_02143 wrote: Money is wildly tight here. The problem? We were never anything but frugal! I don't use coupons to be honest.... the coupons that arrive in the Sunday paper are not for ingredients, but for processed foods. Ways we try to save money. We reviewed our cable bill and pared it down to what my husband considers to be the essentials. In September we will not renew our cell phone contracts, and instead will go on a pre=pay plan since we are not getting enough value for our monthly cost. We keep the house VERY cold. We close the doors to the rooms that we don't have to use and turn off their radiators. We have reduced the amount of meat that we eat to about 4 oz a day, and in general do not eat the three-part meals anymore. We make everything from scratch with very few exceptions. Since there are only two of us in the house now, I make larger pots of everything and freeze the leftovers already portioned. We buy household goods like paper towels at a warehouse store, along with many food items. Again we utilize that freezer. [Best investment ever if you have a place to put it!] This summer we are refurbishing a bathroom so we can rent out a room. Turns out this room is worth $650.00 a month for a single occupant! If we rent to an ESL student, the income isn't taxable. I don't buy clothes. Gaining weight is simply not an option anymore. Last year my personal budget was $235 and that is only because I had to attend a wedding with two events. My husband buys clothes more frequently, but will only purchase something that is at least 60% off. When we do splurge, it tends to be a raw ingredient that we can make at home like a steak. But we still only eat a bit at that first meal. The next day, we will have a big green salad with some of the leftovers, and then the next day it appears in a burrito. I think this is really hard for the kids. It is hard to be the one "without." When our child was still living with us, we would give her a budget for "special" things, and in her head she bought a gazillion things. And then she would buy the thing that gave her the most pleasure, but she felt like she had bought and returned all those other items. For some reason this helped her not feel deprived. Nothing here that you haven't considered already. Maybe it helps to know that you are not alone with this financial squeeze. *susan*

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2011 11:53AM - edited Oct 15, 2011 11:54AM by susan_02143 Wow. You wait that long for a ten minute appointment? That would irritate the crap out of me. My hospital has an "on time" policy. If for any reason [and sometimes I have been that reason] the doctor can not see you at your scheduled time, a nurse is sent to the waiting room to tell you exactly what is happening and a vague why. My oncologist, who I saw every 6 months for a few years, would spend 30 minutes with me. The first 20 minutes were mostly chatting about how I felt, any new ethnic restaurants we had tried, and whatever else seemed to come up. Then there was a 5 minute physical exam, and ending with writing up the lab request and any scans that he thought might be needed. The month that I reported a lot of pains and concerns, he and his PA jumped into overdrive and had me in a scanner within 24 hrs. My time with my oncologist was never a waste. My only regret is that we got a little too casual about spacing, but two months would not have made a difference. I wish all of you had a doctor that shows such great concern about the patient in the room at that moment. *susan*  p.s. and no waiting for lab results. Just log onto their website, run your credentials, and there they all are.

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 03:50PM susan_02143 wrote: Ugh. Let's face it, this person would be difficult regardless of her relative's health. In fact, her relative's health and your work really aren't part of the same discussion. However, your health is relevant if this mistake was made because you didn't feel well. But, that isn't really part of the discussion either. You made an error. She is upset. When I have had moments like this with a client, I simply respond with. "Yes, I made an error. I am terribly sorry that this happened. What do you want me to do to make this better?" They are allowed one opportunity to vent, but then I want to know the solution. And if none of the solutions I suggest are right, then they need to tell me what they actually want. So often, they just want to fuss. I don't have any interest in extended fussing. Let's move on! Good luck! *susan*

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2012 03:08PM susan_02143 wrote: I love data. I love science. I love logic. I have seen Western medicine win signifigant battles; and I have mourned those that couldn't be saved with the knowledge that we currently possess. One of my BCO sisters took out bank loans to buy a full cabinet of voodoo syringes and potions. I suspect that her husband is still paying for what she called "that stuff." If I am going to put anything into my body, a flawed body, I want to know that somewhere there was a group of strong people who were willing to be guinea pigs and that the treatments that they were given show promise for me. My sister was part of a Phase 1 study that has affected most of us. She is a hero [and still alive!] I will not be traveling to Mexico except to enjoy some Mole. Nor will I buy "supplements" that have unknown ingredients. I do my best to live a balanced life. I make three healthy meals a day [though I only eat two of them]. I buy food from my local farms. I love food and during the two week asparagus season I eat as many stalks as possible. But not because I  think this will be my cure, but because they are delicious. When the time comes, and there are no known treatments that can give me hope, I will gladly participate in any trial that might help future generations. I don't believe that "I will be the one." My life experience doesn't give me that kind of optimism, and I love my life! Just a few more thoughts. *susan*

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2016 03:28PM susan_02143 wrote: Malissa... Welcome! Armidex and Femara are not actually chemotherapy. They are aromatase inhibitors. Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2010 09:54PM susan_02143 wrote: Bruburn, Regression is good. Knowing your medical status is priceless. You might want to have a talk with yourself one day. What do you need from your medical team? How involved do you want to be in your treatment plan? How transparent do you need your doctors to be with you? And then match your wishes to what your team is doing. If they don't match, you can either discuss it with them, or simply find someone who matched what you need. I have chosen to be intimately involved in my care. I get copies of every scan, every blood test, and I have spent time learning how to read these reports. My oncologist is very comfortable with my involvement, and in some ways, finds it exciting. Enjoy the good news. And then find the strength to figure out what kind of patient you want to be. All the best, *susan*

Posts.Content: susan_02143 wrote: Dr Roger, my oncologist and friend, died on January 19, 2012. The inside of my bones feel cold. He so deserved to have a retirement with his wife. At 68, his life was cut far too short. His leave of absence has been hard for me to deal with; his death seems too cruel to absorb. = Roger Frederick Lange, one of Boston's pre-eminent hematologists and oncologists, died January 19, 2012 from complications of multiple myeloma. He was known for his keen intellect, expansive knowledge, excellent judgment, and outstanding personal care of his patients, and over his career became one of the most sought after cancer clinicians in Boston.  Dr. Lange served as a faculty member of the Harvard Medical School for 37 years, and was a source of inspiration and a role model, devoting as much care and energy to training young physicians as he did to taking care of his patients.  Born in 1943 in Chicago, Roger was a graduate of Chicago's South Shore High School class of 1961 where he excelled in baseball and basketball. He graduated from Harvard College, summa cum laude, in 1961, and from the Harvard Medical School, cum laude, in 1969.  Dr. Lange was selected to join the Residency program in Internal Medicine at Beth Israel Hospital, and thereafter served at the National Institutes of Health under Dr. Raphael Shulman. In 1973, Roger was a post-doctoral hematology/oncology fellow at Washington University in St. Louis, and in 1974, he assumed the role of Chief Resident in Medicine at the Beth Israel Hospital.  Roger has been a member of the hospital staffs of both the Beth Israel and the Mount Auburn Hospitals since the mid-1970s. He became Chief of the Division of Hematology-Oncology at the Mount Auburn Hospital, and remained on the staff of both medical centers until the time of his death. His reputation as a "go-to clinician" and "doctor's doctor" was quickly established, as was his role as a medical educator. He was named as one of "Boston's Best Doctors" by Boston Magazine at least five times during his career, including in 2011. His patients treasured the time they spent with him because he treated each of them with respect and genuinely enjoyed their company. No matter how difficult the news he had to deliver, Roger always managed to have patients feel better leaving the office than they did entering it. The only part of Roger's life that was more important to him than his role as a physician and teacher was his family. He instilled in them his values, his enthusiasm for life's pleasures, and his sense of humor. Despite his busy schedule, he never missed his children's recitals, school plays, or sporting events, or Lois's chamber music events and performances. He and Lois made bicycling trips to several continents and every part of the U.S., sometimes biking one hundred miles a day. He made us all understand the importance of getting things exactly right – whether it was through driving around town for hours looking for the right size, shape, brand or color for whatever it was he was fixing, or solving any other problem, big or small.  Roger was blessed with many friends from each stage of his life.  He lived with joy, compassion, and the highest regard for others, and was widely admired for his honesty, loyalty, moustache, and especially for his sense of humor. Roger's approach to life was embodied in the advice he gave to the nearly one thousand cancer patients and family members attending the Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center's annual "Celebration of Life" event. Urging them to continue to live life to the fullest, out came "Just remember, cancer, shmancer, as long as you've got your health!"  He is survived by his childhood sweetheart and wife of more than forty-four years, Lois (Platt) Lange, son David M. Lange, daughter Nancy Lange Vaidya, daughter-in-law Bernadette Lee, son-in-law Anand Vaidya and his two beloved granddaughters, Maia Vivienne Lange (15 months) and Usha Ranjani Vaidya (3 weeks). He is also survived by his brother, Paul Lange, of Rehoboth, Delaware. anotherplan.blogspot.com... and its back. May 3, 2010 mets found. Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 11:00AM susan_02143 wrote: If your wife is still asking things like "why me?" and "how can I live like this" she is still has a long way to go on the emotional trail. What was she like before all this crap? Was she an easy going "half full" kind of woman, or more "half empty?" If her response seems totally out of character, she really might need to try a therapist. And the first one might not be the right one. Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2014 11:07PM - edited Apr 17, 2014 11:09PM by susan_02143 Well, finally.... something I might be able to help with. Adriamyacin is a strong, strong drug, but it works. I did four of those infusions way back when I was stage II. Emend is your best friend. Follow the drug regimen religiously. For me, the key was eating tiny meals, every two hours. My routine was oatmeal at 8am. At 10, a small smoothie.... especially the yogurt. Noon was a "standard" meal such as mini quiche, meatball with spaghetti, high protein and high carb. 2pm I would eat a boiled egg. 4pm was something like a mini-quiche. Dinner at 6pm was a small piece of meat with something like a mashed potato. 8pm, gosh, I can't remember..... and then I crawled into bed. I made all of this food during the steroid boost I got during the first three days. I was a cooking fool. Other things I remember are spanikopita [from Costco], a bagel with smoked salmon, more yogurt with frozen fruit, chicken stew with biscuits [ina garten on food network.com], tenderloin steaks on the grill, etc. This is a fairly rigorous protocol, but hundreds of thousands of women have done it as lower stage patients. You can do it! *susan* p.s. I also walked the local supermarket during A/C. Helped keep my energy level up, and man did I learn where everything was displayed. I did the store twice which was a mile. It was winter so walking outside seemed too scary with ice and snow.

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2011 09:43PM susan_02143 wrote: I am. [sorry for those that have read all of this before.] I started on aromasin in December 2005, which clearly didn't work well enough since I was dx'ed with mets 4 years later. At this point, we added a single dose of Faslodex. After 14 months of this, I was declared NED, and changed to a double dose of Faslodex. My side effects have been bone pain, joint pain, neuropathy, fatigue.. at varying degrees. I don't take pain meds, but I sometimes have to take a short nap. Overall, this protocol is pretty easy, and getting to NED makes a few pains seem irrelevant. *susan*

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2015 04:59PM susan_02143 wrote: Nred, No. I am not at Dana Farber. I am across the street at the Beth Israel. Obviously, aromasin failed me, and my doctor was very enthusiastic about Faslodex and so we did both together. Of course, this was _way_ back in 2010 when Faslodex was a fairly new drug. As I recall, my oncologist was seeing in the research studies that people like me, who have maintained NED status for a long time on Faslodex do not get the same positive results from the secondary enabler drugs as folks who are Faslodex-virgins. This was a small part of a much larger discussion. I didn't ask that many questions. Too busy absorbing. After my next scans, this discussion will be more detailed as we weigh the options. She is very involved in both running studies and training the Harvard residents and fellows at the Beth Israel, so has access to some of the raw data in addition to the periodic reports. *susan*

Much prefer a PET to an MRI. *susan*

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2012 04:20PM susan_02143 wrote: PET's are pretty simple. Always my preferred scan. There are some rules and they do seem to vary depending on the scan location. At my hospital, no strenuous activity the day before. Normal lunch and then dinner must be sugar/carb free. I have to admit, I generally make myself a tenderloin steak with hollandaise sauce. [Figure there has to be some benefit to having mets after all!] Another high fat meal 4-5 hours before the scan. No dairy or sugar. Upon arrival they take you to a "quiet room" where they test your blood sugar levels. If they are low enough, you get the radioactive injection and sit, quietly for an hour. My place allows me to work on the computer or read, but other women aren't allowed to do a thing. After the hour has passed you are taken to the machine. At my place, they no longer tie you onto the board. Instead you lie on your back, they put a wedge under the knees, and ask if you can put your arms over your head. 35 minutes later it is done. Again, my hospital does this test in a sun filled room. To be honest, I sleep now. Tech Andrew says that it isn't unusual. Oh... and I bring my own pajama bottoms since I hate the hospital ones. Hope that helps. *susan*

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2015 05:34PM susan_02143 wrote: Well, for once, I am the bummer in the room. Progression.... but still low grade activity, she says. To refresh, my scan three months ago showed that my original mets which had been MIA for four years, were back with a few new ones, and that vague changes noted on the Left Rib, could be a fracture. The chest wall and pleura lining mets have grown and made babies. Well, as I suspected, it was no fracture in my rib either. That one has grown as well. And since that isn't enough good news for one day, my right rib [which I have been complaining about for 18 months] is also popping up little mets. There is also something on my liver. They called it a focal point, with no measurement. The recommendation is that I should have an MRI to evaluate since the PET doesn't do a great job imaging the liver. {SHIT SHIT SHIT!] She is putting me on Xeloda, an oral chemo. Silly her, she suggested I take it with me on my big Window-of-Opportunity trip, but I declined. After she adjusted to the fact that I was actually leaving, she agreed that starting a chemo in a country where I certainly do not speak the language, much less the medical language, was nuts and we can wait until my return. Instead, I had another set of Faslodex shots so that the cancer didn't get six weeks to get stronger. I will have an MRI on the 26th, another oncologist meeting on the 28th, and start the new treatment as soon as I receive the drugs from the specialty pharmacy. I was not expecting regression, I am not surprised about the first rib met being for real, but am quite devastated that there is already another one on the other side and possible liver involvement. *susan*

Posts.Content: susan_02143 wrote: My hospital has lots of volunteers on the 9th floor. All of them were once patients on the oncology/hematology floor at one time or another. Most of them can't ever remember that I am a patient and not another patient's daughter or granddaughter. But about a year ago a younger woman started to volunteer. About my age, give or take a half dozen years, she has a pink ribbon on her name tag, self-identifying as a breast cancer patient. We have become friendly. She is bright, has great taste in clothing, and over the past year I have come to look forward to our short conversations in the waiting room. During the summer I didn't see her. To be honest, I imagined her summering on Martha's Vineyard, Dorset, Vermont, or one the numerous coastal cabin communities that dot the Atlantic Ocean here in New England. Of course, her real life might be taking care of an aging mother in a dreary mill town, but I like my fantasy better.   Anyhow, today she was back and I was quite pleased to see her. She allowed how she has been away and then asked how I had been. Somehow today's conversation probably went over some invisible line into more personal and I mentioned my carpal tunnel issues. She asked if I was XXXXXX on bc.org. I must have blanched since she asked permission to continue. "Of course," I replied.   She continued "There is this FIVE QUESTIONS thing happening on bc.org and there is someone who also has carpal and plays the violin, just like you! I read her post yesterday and said to myself, this is someone I would like to know." I had to laugh as I said "Well you already do!" I have been outed at my hospital!    She is ten years out from her treatment. She so wishes that bc.org had existed back then, especially the reconstruction boards. She reads our forum to try to assist her sister-in-law who is a Stage IV breast cancer patient who has chosen not to know anything about her treatment and options.   [~~~~~~ waving to my nice volunteer]   Under the circumstances, I felt free to ask her for her screen name. She doesn't have one. Has never posted or joined, but finds great strength and information from the posts that we leave.   One of life's random moments.   *susan* anotherplan.blogspot.com... and its back. Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2015 08:37AM susan_02143 wrote: Pam, The PET is easy. I have a "special" diet for dinner the night before, then have to eat that same "diet" at least three hours before the scan. When they bring you back, they take a bit of blood to check your sugar levels, and then assuming you "pass" then they bring in the radioactive stuff. At the BI, it used to arrive in a silver case, but now a large dosing machine arrives instead. I tell them how much I weighed that morning [but most patients actually are weighed] and they use the same needle configuration that drew the blood, to push this stuff into your body. Then you sit in a room, not moving, for an hour. I am allowed to read, listen to music, etc, but since I schedule these things at the crack of dawn, I sleep. They wake me about 10 minutes before I will go in so I can change into my all-cotton yoga pants, put on some warm socks, and use the restroom. [If you bring your own clothing with no metal, you can use that instead of those horrid johnnies.] My PET scan machine is on the 4th floor with lots of natural sunlight. I put my stuff in a corner, and get onto the bench. They center me up, but a wedge under my knees and a pillow under my head. You lie on your back. They have bands of heavy material that they put across my stomach to keep me still. I used to be tied in, but no longer. These bands are like those thunder-calmers for dogs actually. And then they start. The bench goes all the way to the other side of the tube, and then it starts, with the bench slowly working its way back toward the starting spot so the scan can get the right places of the body. It is not wildly loud like an MRI. There is no banana smoothie like the CT. To be honest, I generally sleep some more in the tube. These days, with the new machines, the test takes about 25 minutes. I haven't been given the drink in ages. Not sure why. At the BI, the drink is hidden in fruit juice when they give it. Hope that helps! *susan* p.s. the radioactive stuff seems to have absolutely no side effects. I just want a vegetable and a carb desperately afterwards.

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2016 07:10PM susan_02143 wrote: A change in job status means that you can apply for insurance coverage through healthcare.gov. To quote "a job loss qualifies you for a hardship exemption for 60 days starting at the period you lost coverage. You need to apply for that exemption at HealthCare.Gov and need a copy of your cancellation." With no income, your insurance through Obamacare would be heavily [if not fully] subsidized. The level of coverage through these programs is amazing. Far better in many cases than what I pay about $1800/month for and much better than either of the Medic--- plans. Of course, you must be given the option for COBRA coverage through your husband's ex-employer, but the cost is often prohibitive for anyone without a bunch of savings. If I think of any additional and practical suggestions, I will post back. My heart goes out to you. I just can't imagine how difficult this all must be. *susan*

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2011 03:10PM susan_02143 wrote: Katie, IF you want a long-distance consultation, I would recommend a different place. MDAnderson may or may not be the best center for breast cancer, but they do require that you travel with your records and require that you have new scans done by the them. Sloan Kettering in NYCity, Dana Farber in Boston or Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston will do a second consult without a personal visit. Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2014 04:11PM susan_02143 wrote: One clarification.... COBRA is not more expensive, but you do pay 100% so it is more expensive for you. A small point obviously, but an important one. For people who have employers that offer health insurance, generally, the employer pays a portion of each month's premium. For those of us who do not have an employer, our costs remain the same. The difficulty is, and it is a huge difficulty, is now you don't have any income to cover those expenses. People who work for companies that cover the health insurance costs while their employees are on either type of disability have a great gift. For me, the two years of paying for insurance without income looms large. I am working hard to put enough money away while I am still working to cover those two years. Currently, we pay $1600 a month for two of us for decent coverage. That is a huge savings goal! Some other sources of money are retirement accounts [no penalty for withdrawal once you are disabled], downsizing assuming your community hasn't had a real estate collapsed, and cashing in a life insurance policy, if you have one. As others have mentioned, without income, you might qualify for government subsidized policies, but I believe that your family income has to qualify [not just you.] I will be interested to know how you navigate this pesky, but essential, question. *susan*
